Task: Implement feature wf-c2n on branch feature/wf-c2n-search-priority.

Context:
- Branch feature/wf-c2n-search-priority already created from origin/main and contains local change to .beads/issues.jsonl (preserve it).
- Bead wf-c2n has been updated to status in_progress and is assigned to @map.
- Repository root: /home/rgardler/projects/waif

Goal:
- Add optional positional [search] argument to `waif next` that, when present, biases selection using fuzzy matching (Fuse.js) over a candidate pool selected by selectTopN.
- Implementation must use separate Fuse instances for title and description, combine normalized match scores with boosts (title +20%, desc +10%) using the multiplicative formula below, and fall back to original selection if no candidate matches.

Detailed requirements / acceptance criteria:
1) CLI
  - Add positional argument '[search]' to src/commands/next.ts command builder.
  - When search is not provided, behavior must be identical to current behavior (no changes).
  - When search is provided, use options.number (alias -n) as candidate pool size; default top_n = 10 if options.number is undefined.

2) Candidate selection
  - Use existing selectTopN helper to get top N candidates and their original bv/computed scores. Ensure you preserve the originalScore for each candidate (the bv score used by existing selection logic).

3) Fuzzy matching
  - Add dependency fuse.js (npm install --save fuse.js). Use separate Fuse instances for title and description.
  - Configure Fuse with includeScore: true and reasonable threshold (0.6 is acceptable). Ensure matching is case-insensitive.
  - For the set of candidates, run two searches (titleFuse.search and descFuse.search) with the provided search string to obtain per-candidate match scores.
  - Convert Fuse scores to normalized match strengths in [0,1] where 1 = perfect match and 0 = no match. (Fuse returns score in [0,1] with 0 being exact; use match = 1 - fuseScore). If a candidate is not present in the search results, treat its match score as 0.

4) Adjusted scoring and ranking
  - For each candidate compute adjustedScore = originalScore * (1 + titleBoost * titleMatchScore + descBoost * descMatchScore)
    - titleBoost = 0.20
    - descBoost = 0.10
  - Sort candidates by adjustedScore descending. For deterministic tie-breaking, if adjustedScore equal use originalScore descending, then id lexicographic ascending.

5) No-match fallback
  - If none of the top-N candidates have titleMatchScore > 0 or descMatchScore > 0 (i.e., all zero), treat as no-match: revert to using the original selection from selectTopN (the pre-ranked order) and print a clear human output message: "Search: no-match; using default recommendation".
  - JSON output must remain unchanged in no-match case (same contract as before).

6) Output contract
  - Do NOT add match metadata to JSON output. The --json output must be the same shape as existing behavior: selected issue(s) only.
  - Human output: when a search is applied and matches exist, show the re-ranked list (same table format as current -n behavior) and indicate that search was applied. When no-match, show message noted above and show default recommendation.
  - Clipboard behavior: copy only the first recommended id (same as current behavior), best-effort and must not fail the command.

7) Tests
  - Add unit tests demonstrating:
    a) Search re-ranking: a candidate with slightly lower originalScore should be promoted above a higher-scoring candidate when it has a strong title match for the search string.
    b) No-match fallback: when search matches none of the top-N candidates, fallback to original selection and a visible no-match message.
  - Tests should live in tests/ (either extend tests/next.test.ts or add tests/next-search.test.ts). Use existing test helpers/mocks to create deterministic bv/selectTopN behavior.

8) Quality gates and CI
  - Run npm install to add dependency, run npm run build (if applicable), and npm test locally. Tests must pass.

9) Commits / PR / beads updates
  - Make commits on branch feature/wf-c2n-search-priority. Commit message style:
    "wf-c2n: add search-prioritized re-ranking to waif next (fuse.js, top_n=10, title+20%, desc+10%)"
  - Push branch to origin and open a PR with title "wf-c2n: waif next search-prioritized issue selection". PR body must include:
    - Summary of feature
    - Decisions (Fuse.js, boosts, top_n default 10, positional arg)
    - Tests added and how to run them
    - Any UX notes (no-match fallback behavior, JSON contract unchanged)
  - After PR is created, run: bd update wf-c2n --external-ref "gh-PR: <PR-URL>" --notes "PR opened: <PR-URL>" --json
  - Do NOT close the bead wf-c2n; leave it in_progress until PR merged.

Safety and constraints
- Preserve existing .beads/issues.jsonl content; do not discard the local uncommitted changes.
- Don't change any other CLI JSON output contract or unrelated behavior.
- Keep code deterministic (stable sorts/tie-breakers) to avoid flaky automation.
- If implementation requires refactoring across multiple files, keep changes small and include unit tests for refactors.

Deliverables
- Commits on feature/wf-c2n-search-priority implementing the feature and tests.
- PR URL
- bd update confirming PR link
- CI/test output summary
- A short summary of files changed and commands executed

If you encounter blockers or need decisions (thresholds, Fuse config), ask before proceeding.

Return format: final agent message should include a concise summary of actions taken, commands run, files changed (paths), test results, PR URL, and next recommended steps. If any tests fail or PR cannot be opened, explain errors and next actions.
Use the above message and context to generate a prompt and call the task tool with subagent: map

  - Configure Fuse with includeScore: true and reasonable threshold (0.6 is acceptable). Ensure matching is case-insensitive.
  - For the set of candidates, run two searches (titleFuse.search and descFuse.search) with the provided search string to obtain per-candidate match scores.
  - Convert Fuse scores to normalized match strengths in [0,1] where 1 = perfect match and 0 = no match. (Fuse returns score in [0,1] with 0 being exact; use match = 1 - fuseScore). If a candidate is not present in the search results, treat its match score as 0.

4) Adjusted scoring and ranking
  - For each candidate compute adjustedScore = originalScore * (1 + titleBoost * titleMatchScore + descBoost * descMatchScore)
    - titleBoost = 0.20
    - descBoost = 0.10
  - Sort candidates by adjustedScore descending. For deterministic tie-breaking, if adjustedScore equal use originalScore descending, then id lexicographic ascending.

5) No-match fallback
  - If none of the top-N candidates have titleMatchScore > 0 or descMatchScore > 0 (i.e., all zero), treat as no-match: revert to using the original selection from selectTopN (the pre-ranked order) and print a clear human output message: "Search: no-match; using default recommendation".
  - JSON output must remain unchanged in no-match case (same contract as before).

6) Output contract
  - Do NOT add match metadata to JSON output. The --json output must be the same shape as existing behavior: selected issue(s) only.
  - Human output: when a search is applied and matches exist, show the re-ranked list (same table format as current -n behavior) and indicate that search was applied. When no-match, show message noted above and show default recommendation.
  - Clipboard behavior: copy only the first recommended id (same as current behavior), best-effort and must not fail the command.

7) Tests
  - Add unit tests demonstrating:
    a) Search re-ranking: a candidate with slightly lower originalScore should be promoted above a higher-scoring candidate when it has a strong title match for the search string.
    b) No-match fallback: when search matches none of the top-N candidates, fallback to original selection and a visible no-match message.
  - Tests should live in tests/ (either extend tests/next.test.ts or add tests/next-search.test.ts). Use existing test helpers/mocks to create deterministic bv/selectTopN behavior.

8) Quality gates and CI
  - Run npm install to add dependency, run npm run build (if applicable), and npm test locally. Tests must pass.

9) Commits / PR / beads updates
  - Make commits on branch feature/wf-c2n-search-priority. Commit message style:
    "wf-c2n: add search-prioritized re-ranking to waif next (fuse.js, top_n=10, title+20%, desc+10%)"
  - Push branch to origin and open a PR with title "wf-c2n: waif next search-prioritized issue selection". PR body must include:
    - Summary of feature
    - Decisions (Fuse.js, boosts, top_n default 10, positional arg)
    - Tests added and how to run them
    - Any UX notes (no-match fallback behavior, JSON contract unchanged)
  - After PR is created, run: bd update wf-c2n --external-ref "gh-PR: <PR-URL>" --notes "PR opened: <PR-URL>" --json
  - Do NOT close the bead wf-c2n; leave it in_progress until PR merged.

Safety and constraints
- Preserve existing .beads/issues.jsonl content; do not discard the local uncommitted changes.
- Don't change any other CLI JSON output contract or unrelated behavior.
- Keep code deterministic (stable sorts/tie-breakers) to avoid flaky automation.
- If implementation requires refactoring across multiple files, keep changes small and include unit tests for refactors.

Deliverables
- Commits on feature/wf-c2n-search-priority implementing the feature and tests.
- PR URL
- bd update confirming PR link
- CI/test output summary
- A short summary of files changed and commands executed

If you encounter blockers or need decisions (thresholds, Fuse config), ask before proceeding.

Return format: final agent message should include a concise summary of actions taken, commands run, files changed (paths), test results, PR URL, and next recommended steps. If any tests fail or PR cannot be opened, explain errors and next actions.
Use the above message and context to generate a prompt and call the task tool with subagent: map

parts.text:
Implement two unit tests for the wf-c2n feature on branch patch/wf-c2n-impl.

Requirements:
1) Create a new test file tests/next-search.test.ts with two tests:
   a) 'promotes matching title above higher bv score' — ensures that a candidate with a strong title match is recommended first even when it has a slightly lower original BV score. Use three issues and WAIF_BV_PRIORITY_JSON to set scores; call waif next with -n 3 and the search term, with --json to parse output and assert the first returned item id is the matching candidate.
   b) 'no-match falls back to default recommendation' — ensures when the search term matches none of the top-N candidates, the command prints the no-match message and recommends the top original issue. Use three issues and scores, call waif next -n 3 with a search term that doesn't match, do not use --json (so you can assert the human message is printed). Assert stdout contains 'Search: no-match; using default recommendation' and contains the expected top issue id.

2) Use the existing test helpers style (makeIssues, tmpdir, execa). Set WAIF_NO_COLOR=1 and PATH='' in env to keep output deterministic. Set WAIF_CLIPBOARD_CMD to process.execPath.

3) Run npm run build and npm test locally. If tests pass, commit the new file with message: "test(next): add search re-ranking and no-match tests". Push to origin patch/wf-c2n-impl and update the PR (https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/82) with a short note indicating tests were added.

4) Run bd update wf-c2n --notes "Added unit tests for search re-ranking and no-match fallback; see PR #82" --json to record the change.

Return: concise summary of commands run, files created, test results, commit hash, push/PR update, and any failures.

Do this work on branch patch/wf-c2n-impl. Ask if anything is unclear before proceeding.

parts.text:
You are implementing a Beads issue in this repository.

Argument handling:

- The user should run this as `/implement <bd-id>`.
- Use `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only` as the Beads ID.
- If `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only` is empty/undefined, ask for the missing id and stop.

Project rules (must follow):

- Use `bd` for ALL task tracking; do not create markdown TODOs.
- Keep changes minimal and scoped to the issue.
- Validate changes with the most relevant tests/commands available.
- Use a git branch + PR workflow (no direct-to-main changes).
- Ensure the working branch is pushed to `origin` before you finish.
- Do NOT close the Beads issue until the PR is merged.

Context files:

- Tracker workflow: @AGENTS.md
- Copilot rules: @.github/copilot-instructions.md

Live context (do not guess; use this output):

- Current issue JSON: {
  "error": "resolving ID NOTE: operation failed: failed to resolve ID: no issue found matching \"NOTE\""
}

- Git status: ## main...origin/main
 M .beads/issues.jsonl

- Current branch: main

- Origin remote: git@github.com:SorraTheOrc/waif.git

- Default origin branch (best effort): refs/remotes/origin/main


Process:

0. Safety gate: handle dirty working tree

   - Before making any changes, check whether the working tree is clean (`git status --porcelain=v1 -b`).
   - If there are _any_ uncommitted changes (modified, staged, or untracked files), **stop and ask the user what to do**. Do not assume changes are irrelevant.
   - Offer clear options and wait for an explicit choice:
     - A) Carry changes into this issue branch (continue as-is).
     - B) Commit current changes first (either on current branch or a separate "prep" branch).
     - C) Stash changes (and confirm whether to pop later).
     - D) Revert/discard changes (only with explicit confirmation).
     - E) Abort implementation so the user can inspect.

1. Understand the issue

   - Restate the acceptance criteria and constraints from the issue JSON.
   - Identify dependencies/blockers; if blocked, explain what is missing and ask the user how to proceed.
   - Review the issue `description`, `notes`, and any `comments` for references to PRDs, implementation plans, or other linked docs; if present, open and read those sources before proceeding.

1.1 Definition gate (must do before implementation)

    Before writing any code, confirm the Beads issue is sufficiently well-defined to implement.

    Minimum definition checklist:

    - Clear scope: what is in-scope vs out-of-scope
    - Concrete acceptance criteria (testable, not just aspirational)
    - Constraints/compatibility expectations (if any)
    - Obvious unknowns captured as questions (or resolved)

    If the issue is not sufficiently defined:

    - Stop implementation.
    - Work through the **intake brief interview** first to fully define the work.
       - Use `.opencode/command/intake.md` as the guide for the questions and searches.
       - IMPORTANT: when intake is performed as part of `/implement`, it must **always update the existing issue `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only`**. Do **not** create a new Beads issue.
       - After the intake interview + repo/Beads search, update the current issue so it becomes actionable:
          - Prefer updating the issue `description` and/or `acceptance` with the intake brief output.
          - Example: `bd update wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --description "<intake brief markdown>" --json`
          - Ensure the updated issue contains: problem, users, success criteria, constraints, related docs/issues, clarifying questions, and testable acceptance criteria.
    - Only resume `/implement` once the work item is clearly actionable.

2. Create a working branch

   - If you are already on a topic branch for this issue, or a parent of this issue, keep it.
   - Otherwise create a new branch named like `feature/wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only-<short-suffix>` or `bug/wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only-<short-suffix>`.
   - Do not commit directly on `main`.

3. Claim the issue

   - Run `bd update wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --status in_progress --assignee "$USER" --json`.
   - If `--assignee` is not accepted in this environment, rerun without it.

4. Implement

   - Identify the smallest set of files to change.
   - Make the code changes.
   - If you discover additional required work, create new linked issues using `bd create ... --deps discovered-from:wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --json`.
   - Author appropriate tests that validate the intended behaviour
   - Document the changes in the project documentation

5. Validate

   - Run the most specific checks available for the changed area (tests/lint/build).

6. Update the docs

   - If the issue has linked PRDs or design docs, update them with a summary of the work done, and references to imprtant files altered during the work.
   - Update the `docs/workflow.md` if the issue changes any part of the development workflow.
   - Update any relevant README.md files to reflect changes in usage, setup, or configuration.
   - Update any documents linked from `workflow.md` that are affected by the changes made in this issue.

7. Commit

   - Commit your code changes on the branch (include the Beads id in the commit message).
   - Ensure the commit message is clear and descriptive.

8. Update Beads (do not close)

   - Update the issue to include the PR URL using `--external-ref` and/or `--notes`.
   - Keep the issue in `in_progress` until the PR is merged.
   - Run `bd sync` before ending the session.
     - If there are no Beads changes to commit (or you are on an ephemeral branch without upstream), use `bd sync --flush-only`.
   - Output a summary of the goal of the issue and the work done, including a brief summary of changes to each file. Including a link to the PR. Provide hints on how to test any new functionality locally. Ask the user to review the PR and merge when ready.
   - Ask the producer to provide feedback on the implementation and, if ready to do so, to instruct the agent to "land the plane" (merge the PR and close the issue).

<file>
00001| ## Issue Tracking with bd (beads)
00002| 
00003| **IMPORTANT**: This project uses **bd (beads)** for ALL issue tracking. Do NOT use markdown TODOs, task lists, or other tracking methods.
00004| 
00005| ### Why bd?
00006| 
00007| - Dependency-aware: Track blockers and relationships between issues
00008| - Git-friendly: Auto-syncs to JSONL for version control
00009| - Agent-optimized: JSON output, ready work detection, discovered-from links
00010| - Prevents duplicate tracking systems and confusion
00011| 
00012| ### Quick Start
00013| 
00014| **Check for ready work:**
00015| 
00016| ```bash
00017| bd ready --json
00018| ```
00019| 
00020| **Create new issues:**
00021| 
00022| ```bash
00023| # For bugs and features, use templates for structured documentation
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json
00026| bd create "Epic title" --from-template epic -p 1 --json
00027| 
00028| # For quick tasks/chores, skip templates
00029| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json
00030| bd create "Chore title" -t chore -p 3 --json
00031| 
00032| # With dependencies or parent relationships
00033| bd create "Issue title" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:bd-123 --json
00034| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask (gets ID like epic-id.1)
00035| ```
00036| 
00037| **Claim and update:**
00038| 
00039| ```bash
00040| bd update bd-42 --status in_progress --json
00041| bd update bd-42 --priority 1 --json
00042| ```
00043| 
00044| **Complete work:**
00045| 
00046| ```bash
00047| bd close bd-42 --reason "Completed" --json
00048| ```
00049| 
00050| ### Issue Types
00051| 
00052| - `bug` - Something broken
00053| - `feature` - New functionality
00054| - `task` - Work item (tests, docs, refactoring)
00055| - `epic` - Large feature with subtasks
00056| - `chore` - Maintenance (dependencies, tooling)
00057| 
00058| ### Priorities
00059| 
00060| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00061| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00062| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00063| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00064| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00065| 
00066| ### Workflow for AI Agents
00067| 
00068| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready` shows unblocked issues
00069| 2. **Claim your task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00070| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00071| 4. **Discover new work?** Create linked issue:
00072|    - `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id>`
00073| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done"`
00074| 6. **Commit together**: Always commit the `.beads/issues.jsonl` file together with the code changes so issue state stays in sync with code state
00075| 
00076| ### Using bv as an AI sidecar
00077| 
00078| bv is a fast terminal UI for Beads projects (.beads/beads.jsonl). It renders lists/details and precomputes dependency metrics (PageRank, critical path, cycles, etc.) so you instantly see blockers and execution order. For agents, it’s a graph sidecar: instead of parsing JSONL or risking hallucinated traversal, call the robot flags to get deterministic, dependency-aware outputs.
00079| 
00080| _IMPORTANT: As an agent, you must ONLY use bv with the robot flags, otherwise you'll get stuck in the interactive TUI that's intended for human usage only!_
00081| 
00082| - bv --robot-help — shows all AI-facing commands.
00083| - bv --robot-insights — JSON graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, HITS, critical path, cycles) with top-N summaries for quick triage.
00084| - bv --robot-plan — JSON execution plan: parallel tracks, items per track, and unblocks lists showing what each item frees up.
00085| - bv --robot-priority — JSON priority recommendations with reasoning and confidence.
00086| - bv --robot-recipes — list recipes (default, actionable, blocked, etc.); apply via bv --recipe <name> to pre-filter/sort before other flags.
00087| - bv --robot-diff --diff-since <commit|date> — JSON diff of issue changes, new/closed items, and cycles introduced/resolved.
00088| 
00089| Use these commands instead of hand-rolling graph logic; bv already computes the hard parts so agents can act safely and quickly.
00090| 
00091| ### Auto-Sync
00092| 
00093| bd automatically syncs with git:
00094| 
00095| - Exports to `.beads/issues.jsonl` after changes (5s debounce)
00096| - Imports from JSONL when newer (e.g., after `git pull`)
00097| - No manual export/import needed!
00098| 
00099| ### GitHub Copilot Integration
00100| 
00101| If using GitHub Copilot, also create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for automatic instruction loading.
00102| Run `bd onboard` to get the content, or see step 2 of the onboard instructions.
00103| 
00104| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00105| 
00106| If using Claude or MCP-compatible clients, install the beads MCP server:
00107| 
00108| ```bash
00109| pip install beads-mcp
00110| ```
00111| 
00112| Add to MCP config (e.g., `~/.config/claude/config.json`):
00113| 
00114| ```json
00115| {
00116|   "beads": {
00117|     "command": "beads-mcp",
00118|     "args": []
00119|   }
00120| }
00121| ```
00122| 
00123| Then use `mcp__beads__*` functions instead of CLI commands.
00124| 
00125| ### Managing AI-Generated Planning Documents
00126| 
00127| AI assistants often create planning and design documents during development:
00128| 
00129| - PLAN.md, IMPLEMENTATION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md
00130| - DESIGN.md, CODEBASE_SUMMARY.md, INTEGRATION_PLAN.md
00131| - TESTING_GUIDE.md, TECHNICAL_DESIGN.md, and similar files
00132| 
00133| **Best Practice: Use a dedicated directory for these ephemeral files**
00134| 
00135| **Recommended approach:**
00136| 
00137| - Create a `history/` directory in the project root
00138| - Store ALL AI-generated planning/design docs in `history/`
00139| - Keep the repository root clean and focused on permanent project files
00140| - Only access `history/` when explicitly asked to review past planning
00141| 
00142| **Example .gitignore entry (optional):**
00143| 
00144| ```
00145| # AI planning documents (ephemeral)
00146| history/
00147| ```
00148| 
00149| **Benefits:**
00150| 
00151| - ✅ Clean repository root
00152| - ✅ Clear separation between ephemeral and permanent documentation
00153| - ✅ Easy to exclude from version control if desired
00154| - ✅ Preserves planning history for archeological research
00155| - ✅ Reduces noise when browsing the project
00156| 
00157| ### Templates
00158| 
00159| Beads provides structured templates for better documentation:
00160| 
00161| - **bug**: Includes steps to reproduce, expected/actual behavior, root cause analysis
00162| - **feature**: Includes motivation, use cases, technical design, alternatives considered
00163| - **epic**: Includes overview, success criteria, scope, architecture, dependencies
00164| 
00165| **When to use templates:**
00166| 
00167| - ✅ Use `--from-template bug` for all bug reports (better debugging context)
00168| - ✅ Use `--from-template feature` for new features (captures design decisions)
00169| - ✅ Use `--from-template epic` for large multi-issue projects
00170| - ❌ Skip templates for quick tasks/chores (unnecessary overhead)
00171| 
00172| **View templates:**
00173| 
00174| ```bash
00175| bd template list --json
00176| bd template show bug --json
00177| ```
00178| 
00179| ### CLI Help
00180| 
00181| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00182| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00183| 
00184| ### Important Rules
00185| 
00186| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00187| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00188| - ✅ Use templates (`--from-template`) for bugs, features, and epics
00189| - ✅ Link discovered work with `discovered-from` dependencies
00190| - ✅ Check `bd ready` before asking "what should I work on?"
00191| - ✅ Store AI planning docs in `history/` directory
00192| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00193| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00194| - ❌ Do NOT use external issue trackers
00195| - ❌ Do NOT duplicate tracking systems
00196| - ❌ Do NOT clutter repo root with planning documents
00197| 
00198| For more details, see README.md and QUICKSTART.md.
00199| 
00200| <!-- bv-agent-instructions-v1 -->
00201| 
00202| ---
00203| 
00204| ## Beads Workflow Integration
00205| 
00206| This project uses [beads_viewer](https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer) for issue tracking. Issues are stored in `.beads/` and tracked in git.
00207| 
00208| ### Essential Commands
00209| 
00210| ```bash
00211| # View issues (launches TUI - avoid in automated sessions)
00212| bv
00213| 
00214| # CLI commands for agents (use these instead)
00215| bd ready              # Show issues ready to work (no blockers)
00216| bd list --status=open # All open issues
00217| bd show <id>          # Full issue details with dependencies
00218| bd create --title="..." --type=task --priority=2
00219| bd update <id> --status=in_progress
00220| bd close <id> --reason="Completed"
00221| bd close <id1> <id2>  # Close multiple issues at once
00222| bd sync               # Commit and push changes
00223| ```
00224| 
00225| ### Workflow Pattern
00226| 
00227| 1. **Start**: Run `bd ready` to find actionable work
00228| 2. **Claim**: Use `bd update <id> --status=in_progress`
00229| 3. **Work**: Implement the task on a branch named with the bd id (see naming conventions)
00230| 4. **Complete**: Use `bd close <id>`
00231| 5. **Sync**: Always run `bd sync` at session end
00232| 
00233| Branch guidance (branch-per-bd):
00234| 
00235| - All work MUST be performed on branches that include the bd id. Create a short-lived topic branch from `origin/main` for each bd issue.
00236| - If a branch already exists for the bd issue, reuse it and record your involvement in bd comments.
00237| - Agents and humans should avoid editing files that other agents have claimed in bd unless coordination is documented.
00238| 
00239| ### Key Concepts
00240| 
00241| - **Dependencies**: Issues can block other issues. `bd ready` shows only unblocked work.
00242| - **Priority**: P0=critical, P1=high, P2=medium, P3=low, P4=backlog (use numbers, not words)
00243| - **Types**: task, bug, feature, epic, question, docs
00244| - **Blocking**: `bd dep add <issue> <depends-on>` to add dependencies
00245| 
00246| ### Session Protocol
00247| 
00248| **Before ending any session, run this checklist:**
00249| 
00250| ```bash
00251| git status              # Check what changed
00252| git add <files>         # Stage code changes
00253| bd sync                 # Commit beads changes
00254| git commit -m "..."     # Commit code
00255| bd sync                 # Commit any new beads changes
00256| git push                # Push to remote
00257| ```
00258| 
00259| ### Best Practices
00260| 
00261| - Check `bd ready` at session start to find available work
00262| - Update status as you work (in_progress → closed)
00263| - Create new issues with `bd create` when you discover tasks
00264| - Use descriptive titles and set appropriate priority/type
00265| - Always `bd sync` before ending session
00266| 
00267| <!-- end-bv-agent-instructions -->
00268| 
00269| ## Landing the Plane (Session Completion)
00270| 
00271| **When ending a work session**, you MUST complete ALL steps below. Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds.
00272| 
00273| **MANDATORY WORKFLOW:**
00274| 
00275| 1. **File issues for remaining work** - Create issues for anything that needs follow-up
00276| 2. **Run quality gates** (if code changed) - Tests, linters, builds, stop the landing if a test fails
00277| 3. **Document changes** - Update docs, changelogs, comments
00278| 4. **PUSH TO REMOTE** - This is MANDATORY:
00279|    ```bash
00280|    git pull --rebase
00281|    bd sync
00282|    git push
00283|    git status  # MUST show "up to date with origin"
00284|    ```
00285| 5. **Raise a PR** (if applicable, ask if unsure) - Link to issues and update the BD with a link to the PR.
00286| 6. Notify the producer that the PR is ready for review. Stop this process until the PR is reviewed and merged. Once reviewed and merged, proceed.
00287| 7. **Update issue status** - Close finished work, update in-progress items
00288| 8. **Clean up** - Clear stashes, prune remote branches
00289| 9. **Verify** - All changes committed AND pushed
00290| 10. **Hand off** - Provide context for next session
00291| **CRITICAL RULES:**
00292| 
00293| - Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds
00294| - NEVER stop before pushing - that leaves work stranded locally
00295| - NEVER say "ready to push when you are" - YOU must push
00296| - If push fails, resolve and retry until it succeeds
00297| - When using backticks in strings that are to be passed as arguments to shell commands (e.g. waif, gh), escape them properly to avoid errors
00298| 
00299| ## Project structure
00300| 
00301| - Source code lives in `src/`
00302| - Tests live in `tests/`
00303| - Documentation lives in `docs/`
00304| - AI-generated planning docs go in `history/` (ephemeral)
00305| - Beads configs live in `.beads/`
00306| - Beads issues live in `.beads/issues.jsonl`
00307| - OpenCode configs live in `.opencode`
00308| - OpenCode agent commands live in `.opencode/command/` - these are not related to the WAFI CLI itself
00309| 

(End of file - total 309 lines)
</file>

parts.text:
You are implementing a Beads issue in this repository.

Argument handling:

- The user should run this as `/implement <bd-id>`.
- Use `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only` as the Beads ID.
- If `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only` is empty/undefined, ask for the missing id and stop.

Project rules (must follow):

- Use `bd` for ALL task tracking; do not create markdown TODOs.
- Keep changes minimal and scoped to the issue.
- Validate changes with the most relevant tests/commands available.
- Use a git branch + PR workflow (no direct-to-main changes).
- Ensure the working branch is pushed to `origin` before you finish.
- Do NOT close the Beads issue until the PR is merged.

Context files:

- Tracker workflow: @AGENTS.md
- Copilot rules: @.github/copilot-instructions.md

Live context (do not guess; use this output):

- Current issue JSON: {
  "error": "resolving ID NOTE: operation failed: failed to resolve ID: no issue found matching \"NOTE\""
}

- Git status: ## main...origin/main
 M .beads/issues.jsonl

- Current branch: main

- Origin remote: git@github.com:SorraTheOrc/waif.git

- Default origin branch (best effort): refs/remotes/origin/main


Process:

0. Safety gate: handle dirty working tree

   - Before making any changes, check whether the working tree is clean (`git status --porcelain=v1 -b`).
   - If there are _any_ uncommitted changes (modified, staged, or untracked files), **stop and ask the user what to do**. Do not assume changes are irrelevant.
   - Offer clear options and wait for an explicit choice:
     - A) Carry changes into this issue branch (continue as-is).
     - B) Commit current changes first (either on current branch or a separate "prep" branch).
     - C) Stash changes (and confirm whether to pop later).
     - D) Revert/discard changes (only with explicit confirmation).
     - E) Abort implementation so the user can inspect.

1. Understand the issue

   - Restate the acceptance criteria and constraints from the issue JSON.
   - Identify dependencies/blockers; if blocked, explain what is missing and ask the user how to proceed.
   - Review the issue `description`, `notes`, and any `comments` for references to PRDs, implementation plans, or other linked docs; if present, open and read those sources before proceeding.

1.1 Definition gate (must do before implementation)

    Before writing any code, confirm the Beads issue is sufficiently well-defined to implement.

    Minimum definition checklist:

    - Clear scope: what is in-scope vs out-of-scope
    - Concrete acceptance criteria (testable, not just aspirational)
    - Constraints/compatibility expectations (if any)
    - Obvious unknowns captured as questions (or resolved)

    If the issue is not sufficiently defined:

    - Stop implementation.
    - Work through the **intake brief interview** first to fully define the work.
       - Use `.opencode/command/intake.md` as the guide for the questions and searches.
       - IMPORTANT: when intake is performed as part of `/implement`, it must **always update the existing issue `wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only`**. Do **not** create a new Beads issue.
       - After the intake interview + repo/Beads search, update the current issue so it becomes actionable:
          - Prefer updating the issue `description` and/or `acceptance` with the intake brief output.
          - Example: `bd update wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --description "<intake brief markdown>" --json`
          - Ensure the updated issue contains: problem, users, success criteria, constraints, related docs/issues, clarifying questions, and testable acceptance criteria.
    - Only resume `/implement` once the work item is clearly actionable.

2. Create a working branch

   - If you are already on a topic branch for this issue, or a parent of this issue, keep it.
   - Otherwise create a new branch named like `feature/wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only-<short-suffix>` or `bug/wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only-<short-suffix>`.
   - Do not commit directly on `main`.

3. Claim the issue

   - Run `bd update wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --status in_progress --assignee "$USER" --json`.
   - If `--assignee` is not accepted in this environment, rerun without it.

4. Implement

   - Identify the smallest set of files to change.
   - Make the code changes.
   - If you discover additional required work, create new linked issues using `bd create ... --deps discovered-from:wf-ba2.5.2 NOTE no code changes, docs only --json`.
   - Author appropriate tests that validate the intended behaviour
   - Document the changes in the project documentation

5. Validate

   - Run the most specific checks available for the changed area (tests/lint/build).

6. Update the docs

   - If the issue has linked PRDs or design docs, update them with a summary of the work done, and references to imprtant files altered during the work.
   - Update the `docs/workflow.md` if the issue changes any part of the development workflow.
   - Update any relevant README.md files to reflect changes in usage, setup, or configuration.
   - Update any documents linked from `workflow.md` that are affected by the changes made in this issue.

7. Commit

   - Commit your code changes on the branch (include the Beads id in the commit message).
   - Ensure the commit message is clear and descriptive.

8. Update Beads (do not close)

   - Update the issue to include the PR URL using `--external-ref` and/or `--notes`.
   - Keep the issue in `in_progress` until the PR is merged.
   - Run `bd sync` before ending the session.
     - If there are no Beads changes to commit (or you are on an ephemeral branch without upstream), use `bd sync --flush-only`.
   - Output a summary of the goal of the issue and the work done, including a brief summary of changes to each file. Including a link to the PR. Provide hints on how to test any new functionality locally. Ask the user to review the PR and merge when ready.
   - Ask the producer to provide feedback on the implementation and, if ready to do so, to instruct the agent to "land the plane" (merge the PR and close the issue).

00001| ## Issue Tracking with bd (beads)
00002| 
00003| **IMPORTANT**: This project uses **bd (beads)** for ALL issue tracking. Do NOT use markdown TODOs, task lists, or other tracking methods.
00004| 
00005| ### Why bd?
00006| 
00007| - Dependency-aware: Track blockers and relationships between issues
00008| - Git-friendly: Auto-syncs to JSONL for version control
00009| - Agent-optimized: JSON output, ready work detection, discovered-from links
00010| - Prevents duplicate tracking systems and confusion
00011| 
00012| ### Quick Start
00013| 
00014| **Check for ready work:**
00015| 
00016| ```bash
00017| bd ready --json
00018| ```
00019| 
00020| **Create new issues:**
00021| 
00022| ```bash
00023| # For bugs and features, use templates for structured documentation
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json
00026| bd create "Epic title" --from-template epic -p 1 --json
00027| 
00028| # For quick tasks/chores, skip templates
00029| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json
00030| bd create "Chore title" -t chore -p 3 --json
00031| 
00032| # With dependencies or parent relationships
00033| bd create "Issue title" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:bd-123 --json
00034| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask (gets ID like epic-id.1)
00035| ```
00036| 
00037| **Claim and update:**
00038| 
00039| ```bash
00040| bd update bd-42 --status in_progress --json
00041| bd update bd-42 --priority 1 --json
00042| ```
00043| 
00044| **Complete work:**
00045| 
00046| ```bash
00047| bd close bd-42 --reason "Completed" --json
00048| ```
00049| 
00050| ### Issue Types
00051| 
00052| - `bug` - Something broken
00053| - `feature` - New functionality
00054| - `task` - Work item (tests, docs, refactoring)
00055| - `epic` - Large feature with subtasks
00056| - `chore` - Maintenance (dependencies, tooling)
00057| 
00058| ### Priorities
00059| 
00060| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00061| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00062| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00063| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00064| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00065| 
00066| ### Workflow for AI Agents
00067| 
00068| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready` shows unblocked issues
00069| 2. **Claim your task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00070| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00071| 4. **Discover new work?** Create linked issue:
00072|    - `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id>`
00073| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done"`
00074| 6. **Commit together**: Always commit the `.beads/issues.jsonl` file together with the code changes so issue state stays in sync with code state
00075| 
00076| ### Using bv as an AI sidecar
00077| 
00078| bv is a fast terminal UI for Beads projects (.beads/beads.jsonl). It renders lists/details and precomputes dependency metrics (PageRank, critical path, cycles, etc.) so you instantly see blockers and execution order. For agents, it’s a graph sidecar: instead of parsing JSONL or risking hallucinated traversal, call the robot flags to get deterministic, dependency-aware outputs.
00079| 
00080| _IMPORTANT: As an agent, you must ONLY use bv with the robot flags, otherwise you'll get stuck in the interactive TUI that's intended for human usage only!_
00081| 
00082| - bv --robot-help — shows all AI-facing commands.
00083| - bv --robot-insights — JSON graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, HITS, critical path, cycles) with top-N summaries for quick triage.
00084| - bv --robot-plan — JSON execution plan: parallel tracks, items per track, and unblocks lists showing what each item frees up.
00085| - bv --robot-priority — JSON priority recommendations with reasoning and confidence.
00086| - bv --robot-recipes — list recipes (default, actionable, blocked, etc.); apply via bv --recipe <name> to pre-filter/sort before other flags.
00087| - bv --robot-diff --diff-since <commit|date> — JSON diff of issue changes, new/closed items, and cycles introduced/resolved.
00088| 
00089| Use these commands instead of hand-rolling graph logic; bv already computes the hard parts so agents can act safely and quickly.
00090| 
00091| ### Auto-Sync
00092| 
00093| bd automatically syncs with git:
00094| 
00095| - Exports to `.beads/issues.jsonl` after changes (5s debounce)
00096| - Imports from JSONL when newer (e.g., after `git pull`)
00097| - No manual export/import needed!
00098| 
00099| ### GitHub Copilot Integration
00100| 
00101| If using GitHub Copilot, also create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for automatic instruction loading.
00102| Run `bd onboard` to get the content, or see step 2 of the onboard instructions.
00103| 
00104| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00105| 
00106| If using Claude or MCP-compatible clients, install the beads MCP server:
00107| 
00108| ```bash
00109| pip install beads-mcp
00110| ```
00111| 
00112| Add to MCP config (e.g., `~/.config/claude/config.json`):
00113| 
00114| ```json
00115| {
00116|   "beads": {
00117|     "command": "beads-mcp",
00118|     "args": []
00119|   }
00120| }
00121| ```
00122| 
00123| Then use `mcp__beads__*` functions instead of CLI commands.
00124| 
00125| ### Managing AI-Generated Planning Documents
00126| 
00127| AI assistants often create planning and design documents during development:
00128| 
00129| - PLAN.md, IMPLEMENTATION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md
00130| - DESIGN.md, CODEBASE_SUMMARY.md, INTEGRATION_PLAN.md
00131| - TESTING_GUIDE.md, TECHNICAL_DESIGN.md, and similar files
00132| 
00133| **Best Practice: Use a dedicated directory for these ephemeral files**
00134| 
00135| **Recommended approach:**
00136| 
00137| - Create a `history/` directory in the project root
00138| - Store ALL AI-generated planning/design docs in `history/`
00139| - Keep the repository root clean and focused on permanent project files
00140| - Only access `history/` when explicitly asked to review past planning
00141| 
00142| **Example .gitignore entry (optional):**
00143| 
00144| ```
00145| # AI planning documents (ephemeral)
00146| history/
00147| ```
00148| 
00149| **Benefits:**
00150| 
00151| - ✅ Clean repository root
00152| - ✅ Clear separation between ephemeral and permanent documentation
00153| - ✅ Easy to exclude from version control if desired
00154| - ✅ Preserves planning history for archeological research
00155| - ✅ Reduces noise when browsing the project
00156| 
00157| ### Templates
00158| 
00159| Beads provides structured templates for better documentation:
00160| 
00161| - **bug**: Includes steps to reproduce, expected/actual behavior, root cause analysis
00162| - **feature**: Includes motivation, use cases, technical design, alternatives considered
00163| - **epic**: Includes overview, success criteria, scope, architecture, dependencies
00164| 
00165| **When to use templates:**
00166| 
00167| - ✅ Use `--from-template bug` for all bug reports (better debugging context)
00168| - ✅ Use `--from-template feature` for new features (captures design decisions)
00169| - ✅ Use `--from-template epic` for large multi-issue projects
00170| - ❌ Skip templates for quick tasks/chores (unnecessary overhead)
00171| 
00172| **View templates:**
00173| 
00174| ```bash
00175| bd template list --json
00176| bd template show bug --json
00177| ```
00178| 
00179| ### CLI Help
00180| 
00181| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00182| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00183| 
00184| ### Important Rules
00185| 
00186| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00187| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00188| - ✅ Use templates (`--from-template`) for bugs, features, and epics
00189| - ✅ Link discovered work with `discovered-from` dependencies
00190| - ✅ Check `bd ready` before asking "what should I work on?"
00191| - ✅ Store AI planning docs in `history/` directory
00192| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00193| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00194| - ❌ Do NOT use external issue trackers
00195| - ❌ Do NOT duplicate tracking systems
00196| - ❌ Do NOT clutter repo root with planning documents
00197| 
00198| For more details, see README.md and QUICKSTART.md.
00199| 
00200| <!-- bv-agent-instructions-v1 -->
00201| 
00202| ---
00203| 
00204| ## Beads Workflow Integration
00205| 
00206| This project uses [beads_viewer](https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer) for issue tracking. Issues are stored in `.beads/` and tracked in git.
00207| 
00208| ### Essential Commands
00209| 
00210| ```bash
00211| # View issues (launches TUI - avoid in automated sessions)
00212| bv
00213| 
00214| # CLI commands for agents (use these instead)
00215| bd ready              # Show issues ready to work (no blockers)
00216| bd list --status=open # All open issues
00217| bd show <id>          # Full issue details with dependencies
00218| bd create --title="..." --type=task --priority=2
00219| bd update <id> --status=in_progress
00220| bd close <id> --reason="Completed"
00221| bd close <id1> <id2>  # Close multiple issues at once
00222| bd sync               # Commit and push changes
00223| ```
00224| 
00225| ### Workflow Pattern
00226| 
00227| 1. **Start**: Run `bd ready` to find actionable work
00228| 2. **Claim**: Use `bd update <id> --status=in_progress`
00229| 3. **Work**: Implement the task on a branch named with the bd id (see naming conventions)
00230| 4. **Complete**: Use `bd close <id>`
00231| 5. **Sync**: Always run `bd sync` at session end
00232| 
00233| Branch guidance (branch-per-bd):
00234| 
00235| - All work MUST be performed on branches that include the bd id. Create a short-lived topic branch from `origin/main` for each bd issue.
00236| - If a branch already exists for the bd issue, reuse it and record your involvement in bd comments.
00237| - Agents and humans should avoid editing files that other agents have claimed in bd unless coordination is documented.
00238| 
00239| ### Key Concepts
00240| 
00241| - **Dependencies**: Issues can block other issues. `bd ready` shows only unblocked work.
00242| - **Priority**: P0=critical, P1=high, P2=medium, P3=low, P4=backlog (use numbers, not words)
00243| - **Types**: task, bug, feature, epic, question, docs
00244| - **Blocking**: `bd dep add <issue> <depends-on>` to add dependencies
00245| 
00246| ### Session Protocol
00247| 
00248| **Before ending any session, run this checklist:**
00249| 
00250| ```bash
00251| git status              # Check what changed
00252| git add <files>         # Stage code changes
00253| bd sync                 # Commit beads changes
00254| git commit -m "..."     # Commit code
00255| bd sync                 # Commit any new beads changes
00256| git push                # Push to remote
00257| ```
00258| 
00259| ### Best Practices
00260| 
00261| - Check `bd ready` at session start to find available work
00262| - Update status as you work (in_progress → closed)
00263| - Create new issues with `bd create` when you discover tasks
00264| - Use descriptive titles and set appropriate priority/type
00265| - Always `bd sync` before ending session
00266| 
00267| <!-- end-bv-agent-instructions -->
00268| 
00269| ## Landing the Plane (Session Completion)
00270| 
00271| **When ending a work session**, you MUST complete ALL steps below. Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds.
00272| 
00273| **MANDATORY WORKFLOW:**
00274| 
00275| 1. **File issues for remaining work** - Create issues for anything that needs follow-up
00276| 2. **Run quality gates** (if code changed) - Tests, linters, builds, stop the landing if a test fails
00277| 3. **Document changes** - Update docs, changelogs, comments
00278| 4. **PUSH TO REMOTE** - This is MANDATORY:
00279|    ```bash
00280|    git pull --rebase
00281|    bd sync
00282|    git push
00283|    git status  # MUST show "up to date with origin"
00284|    ```
00285| 5. **Raise a PR** (if applicable, ask if unsure) - Link to issues and update the BD with a link to the PR.
00286| 6. Notify the producer that the PR is ready for review. Stop this process until the PR is reviewed and merged. Once reviewed and merged, proceed.
00287| 7. **Update issue status** - Close finished work, update in-progress items
00288| 8. **Clean up** - Clear stashes, prune remote branches
00289| 9. **Verify** - All changes committed AND pushed
00290| 10. **Hand off** - Provide context for next session
00291| **CRITICAL RULES:**
00292| 
00293| - Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds
00294| - NEVER stop before pushing - that leaves work stranded locally
00295| - NEVER say "ready to push when you are" - YOU must push
00296| - If push fails, resolve and retry until it succeeds
00297| - When using backticks in strings that are to be passed as arguments to shell commands (e.g. waif, gh), escape them properly to avoid errors
00298| 
00299| ## Project structure
00300| 
00301| - Source code lives in `src/`
00302| - Tests live in `tests/`
00303| - Documentation lives in `docs/`
00304| - AI-generated planning docs go in `history/` (ephemeral)
00305| - Beads configs live in `.beads/`
00306| - Beads issues live in `.beads/issues.jsonl`
00307| - OpenCode configs live in `.opencode`
00308| - OpenCode agent commands live in `.opencode/command/` - these are not related to the WAFI CLI itself
00309| 

(End of file - total 309 lines)
</file>

00001| # GitHub Copilot Instructions
00002| 
00003| ## Issue Tracking with bd
00004| 
00005| This project uses **bd (beads)** for issue tracking - a Git-backed tracker designed for AI-supervised coding workflows.
00006| 
00007| **Key Features:**
00008| - Dependency-aware issue tracking
00009| - Auto-sync with Git via JSONL
00010| - AI-optimized CLI with JSON output
00011| - Built-in daemon for background operations
00012| - MCP server integration for Claude and other AI assistants
00013| 
00014| **CRITICAL**: Use bd for ALL task tracking. Do NOT create markdown TODO lists.
00015| 
00016| ### Essential Commands
00017| 
00018| ```bash
00019| # Find work
00020| bd ready --json                    # Unblocked issues
00021| bd stale --days 30 --json          # Forgotten issues
00022| 
00023| # Create and manage
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json  # Use template for bugs
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json  # Use template for features
00026| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json  # Skip template for tasks
00027| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask
00028| bd update <id> --status in_progress --json
00029| bd close <id> --reason "Done" --json
00030| 
00031| # Search
00032| bd list --status open --priority 1 --json
00033| bd show <id> --json
00034| 
00035| # Sync (CRITICAL at end of session!)
00036| bd sync  # Force immediate export/commit/push
00037| ```
00038| 
00039| ### Workflow
00040| 
00041| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready --json`
00042| 2. **Claim task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00043| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00044| 4. **Discover new work?** `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id> --json`
00045| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done" --json`
00046| 6. **Sync**: `bd sync` (flushes changes to git immediately)
00047| 
00048| ### Priorities
00049| 
00050| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00051| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00052| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00053| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00054| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00055| 
00056| ### Git Workflow
00057| 
00058| - Always commit `.beads/issues.jsonl` with code changes
00059| - Run `bd sync` at end of work sessions
00060| - Install git hooks: `bd hooks install` (ensures DB ↔ JSONL consistency)
00061| 
00062| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00063| 
00064| For MCP-compatible clients (Claude Desktop, etc.), install the beads MCP server:
00065| - Install: `pip install beads-mcp`
00066| - Functions: `mcp__beads__ready()`, `mcp__beads__create()`, etc.
00067| 
00068| ## CLI Help
00069| 
00070| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00071| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00072| 
00073| ## Templates
00074| 
00075| Use templates for structured documentation:
00076| - `--from-template bug` for bug reports (includes steps to reproduce, root cause)
00077| - `--from-template feature` for features (includes motivation, design, alternatives)
00078| - `--from-template epic` for large projects (includes scope, architecture)
00079| - Skip templates for quick tasks/chores
00080| 
00081| ## Important Rules
00082| 
00083| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00084| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00085| - ✅ Use templates for bugs, features, and epics
00086| - ✅ Run `bd sync` at end of sessions
00087| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00088| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00089| - ❌ Do NOT commit `.beads/beads.db` (JSONL only)
00090|

parts.text:
You are the scribbler agent. Make a docs-only change to this repository on branch feature/wf-ba2.5.2-docs-only. Do NOT change source code or tests. Follow these exact steps and return a single message summarizing actions, file diffs, commands run, PR URL, and bead state changes.

1) Verify current branch is feature/wf-ba2.5.2-docs-only and working tree is clean except for expected docs changes. If branch is different, abort and report.

2) Edit docs/dev/context_selection_strategy.md to add a new subsection after the Packaging rules section with heading: "Repository tracking metadata (Beads)". Insert the following content verbatim (preserve formatting, markdown):

Policy: include only minimal Beads metadata (id, title, status, labels, external_ref, updated_at and a trimmed notes line) when it helps traceability. Do not include the full .beads/issues.jsonl or verbose internal notes. Agents should prefer a live bd/CLI query for current state; if a snapshot is embedded, include an explicit timestamp and redact/truncate notes over 200 characters.

Allowed (to include in a context pack)

- Beads metadata items: id, title, status, priority, labels, external_ref (PR), updated_at, and a one-line summary or notes field (trimmed to ~200 chars).
- Use these only as metadata lines (path: .beads/issues.jsonl pointer + small manifest), not the full JSONL blob.
- Example manifest entry:

  {"id":"wf-ba2.5.2","title":"Context selection strategy","status":"in_progress","labels":["milestone:M4"],"external_ref":"gh-PR: https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/84","updated_at":"2025-12-30T14:06:26Z","notes":"Opened PR https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/84 (docs-only)"}

Disallowed

- Full .beads/issues.jsonl dumps or copying all issues into the context pack.
- Private notes, internal audit lines, or any content from beads that appears to be a secret.
- Historical/verbose blobs that exceed per-file limits.

How agents should consume beads state

- Query live via bd/CLI or API to get current status; prefer live lookup rather than embedding a snapshot.
- If a snapshot is embedded, limit to the allowed metadata fields and include an explicit timestamp and pointer to the source file or bd query used.
- Respect redaction rules: trim notes >200 chars, redact any email/credentials discovered in notes, and mark redactions in the audit manifest.

When to include beads metadata

- During PR review, when generating PRD or context for an ongoing issue, or when requests explicitly reference a bead ID.
- Avoid including beads metadata when building generic context packs for unrelated tasks (it adds noise).

3) Update the Acceptance criteria section in docs/dev/context_selection_strategy.md to include a bullet: "Includes guidance for minimal Beads metadata allowed in context packs (id, title, status, labels, external_ref, updated_at) and an example manifest." If the Acceptance criteria section is absent, add it; otherwise append the bullet.

4) Update history/wf-ba2.5.2-notes.md to append a short note: "Added Beads metadata guidance to docs/dev/context_selection_strategy.md (see PR #84)."

5) Stage and commit the changes with message: "wf-ba2.5.2 docs: include beads metadata guidance (docs-only)". Ensure commit includes .beads if it was modified; do NOT modify .beads unless required. If there are unstaged unrelated changes, abort and report.

6) Run npm test and ensure tests pass. If tests fail, abort and report output.

7) Push the branch to origin and update the existing PR (PR URL is https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/84). If the PR cannot be updated for any reason, create or update a PR and return the PR URL.

8) Update the beads issue wf-ba2.5.2 with bd update to add a note: "Added Beads metadata guidance in docs; updated PR https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/84" and include the PR URL as external_ref if not already present. Then run bd sync.

9) Return a single message listing exactly:
- Files edited (paths)
- Git commands executed (in order)
- Test results (pass/fail and summary)
- PR URL
- Beads issue state after update (output of bd show wf-ba2.5.2 or bd update response)
- Any risks or follow-ups

Do not perform any destructive git commands (no force push, no branch deletions). If any step fails, stop and report the failure and its output.

You are the Ship (DevOps) agent. The Map agent asks you to perform these repository operations and return a single concise report of commands run, outputs, and resulting URLs/status. Be careful to follow non-destructive defaults and run safety checks. Do NOT force-push. If any step fails, stop and report error details. Session context:

- Repo: SorraTheOrc/waif
- PR to land: https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/85 (branch: wf-ba2.5.4.2/merge-prd)
- User reviewed the PR and requested: delete history/prd-context.md from the PR and then merge the PR.

Required steps (exact order):
1. Fetch latest origin and ensure branch wf-ba2.5.4.2/merge-prd is present locally and tracks origin/wf-ba2.5.4.2/merge-prd. Abort with diagnostics if not.
2. Checkout the branch wf-ba2.5.4.2/merge-prd.
3. Verify working tree is clean. Abort with diagnostics if not clean.
4. Remove file history/prd-context.md from the branch (git rm history/prd-context.md). Commit with message: "docs: remove archived prd-context.md per user request".
5. Push the commit to origin on the same branch.
6. Confirm the PR (#85) reflects the deletion (gh pr view 85 --json files or gh pr diff) and that checks (if any) are pending/passing. Report check statuses.
7. Merge the PR using the repository's preferred merge method (use --merge). Include a merge commit message prefixed with "Merge PR #85: Consolidate Context PRDs" and let GitHub auto-generate body. If branch deletion on merge is allowed, delete the remote branch. If protected rules prevent deletion, leave remote branch intact and report.
8. After merge, run bd close wf-ba2.5.4.2 --reason "Merged PR #85: consolidated Context PRD" --json to close the beads task. Also run bd update wf-ba2.5.4.1 --status open (or leave as-is) — report bead states.
9. Report back with:
   - Exact commands run and key outputs (stdout/stderr truncated to relevant lines)
   - PR merge URL and commit SHA
   - Whether branch was deleted
   - Files changed/removed
   - Beads updates performed and resulting statuses

Safety & constraints:
- Do not run git push --force or git branch -D locally on main
- If CI checks fail or GitHub blocks merging, stop and report the failure and suggested remediation steps
- If bd commands require write lock or import issues, include the bd output

Return a concise final message summarizing success or failure and listing files removed (history/prd-context.md) and PR URL.


Format of final response: short summary + bullet list of commands executed and outputs + PR merge URL + bead updates + any follow-ups.

Proceed and report back.

parts.text:
You are implementing a Beads issue in this repository.

Argument handling:

- The user should run this as `/implement <bd-id>`.
- Use `wf-ba2.5.4.1` as the Beads ID.
- If `wf-ba2.5.4.1` is empty/undefined, ask for the missing id and stop.

Project rules (must follow):

- Use `bd` for ALL task tracking; do not create markdown TODOs.
- Keep changes minimal and scoped to the issue.
- Validate changes with the most relevant tests/commands available.
- Use a git branch + PR workflow (no direct-to-main changes).
- Ensure the working branch is pushed to `origin` before you finish.
- Do NOT close the Beads issue until the PR is merged.

Context files:

- Tracker workflow: @AGENTS.md
- Copilot rules: @.github/copilot-instructions.md

Live context (do not guess; use this output):

- Current issue JSON: [
  {
    "id": "wf-ba2.5.4.1",
    "title": "Implement 'waif ctx' CLI command (MVP)",
    "description": "Acceptance criteria:\\n-  (alias ) CLI entrypoint exists (src/commands/context.ts or integrated into existing CLI)\\n- Supports flags: --out (default docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md), --force, --max-tokens\\n- Generates docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md from a stable template and writes file to disk\\n- Respects .gitignore (no ignored file contents included)\\n- Unit tests for argument parsing and basic generation are provided\\nNotes: Implementation agent (@patch) should not hardcode PM assignment for overflow issues; create a helper to request Map coordination for strategy.",
    "status": "in_progress",
    "priority": 2,
    "issue_type": "task",
    "created_at": "2025-12-30T14:36:30.146083786-08:00",
    "updated_at": "2025-12-30T14:46:33.295496524-08:00",
    "dependencies": [
      {
        "id": "wf-ba2.5.4",
        "title": "Context Pack command (waif ctx): Intake brief",
        "description": "Linked PRD: docs/dev/context_pack_PRD.md\n\nProblem\n- Agents starting work on a new issue need to understand the project’s overall purpose, structure, and operating rules.\n- Today that context is spread across many files and is not optimized for agent consumption, increasing time-to-first-contribution and raising the risk that agents miss critical workflow/guardrail information.\n- Implement this early, before the repo grows large enough that agents cannot efficiently discover what they need.\n\nUsers\n- Primary: workflow agents starting a new Beads issue (they should consult the context pack at the start of each new issue).\n- Secondary: the Map agent (periodically maintains accuracy of the context pack); the PM indirectly benefits via faster/safer agent execution.\n\nSuccess criteria\n- `waif context` (alias: `waif ctx`) generates/updates a single agent-oriented “signpost” document: `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md`.\n- The context pack provides “minimum efficient” discovery:\n  - Links to all important docs (PRDs/specs, user docs, workflow rules, issue tracking rules, agent roles, key source folders).\n  - Each entry includes a short description (1–2 bullets) describing what it contains and when to read it.\n  - Large docs may be referenced multiple times, pointing at specific sections.\n- The pack avoids rapidly-changing content; instead it points to the canonical way to query it (e.g., it does not list active Beads issues, but explains how to query for ready/active work).\n- Soft size limit: ~20,000 tokens.\n  - If generation exceeds the limit, still write the file AND create/update a P0 Beads issue assigned to the PM flagging that the context pack has exceeded the target and needs strategy/partitioning.\n\nConstraints\n- Ignore/redaction boundaries are defined by `.gitignore`.\n  - Ignored content must not be included; Process:

0. Safety gate: handle dirty working tree

   - Before making any changes, check whether the working tree is clean (`git status --porcelain=v1 -b`).
   - If there are _any_ uncommitted changes (modified, staged, or untracked files), **stop and ask the user what to do**. Do not assume changes are irrelevant.
   - Offer clear options and wait for an explicit choice:
     - A) Carry changes into this issue branch (continue as-is).
     - B) Commit current changes first (either on current branch or a separate "prep" branch).
     - C) Stash changes (and confirm whether to pop later).
     - D) Revert/discard changes (only with explicit confirmation).
     - E) Abort implementation so the user can inspect.

1. Understand the issue

   - Restate the acceptance criteria and constraints from the issue JSON.
   - Identify dependencies/blockers; if blocked, explain what is missing and ask the user how to proceed.
   - Review the issue `description`, `notes`, and any `comments` for references to PRDs, implementation plans, or other linked docs; if present, open and read those sources before proceeding.

1.1 Definition gate (must do before implementation)

    Before writing any code, confirm the Beads issue is sufficiently well-defined to implement.

    Minimum definition checklist:

    - Clear scope: what is in-scope vs out-of-scope
    - Concrete acceptance criteria (testable, not just aspirational)
    - Constraints/compatibility expectations (if any)
    - Obvious unknowns captured as questions (or resolved)

    If the issue is not sufficiently defined:

    - Stop implementation.
    - Work through the **intake brief interview** first to fully define the work.
       - Use `.opencode/command/intake.md` as the guide for the questions and searches.
       - IMPORTANT: when intake is performed as part of `/implement`, it must **always update the existing issue `wf-ba2.5.4.1`**. Do **not** create a new Beads issue.
       - After the intake interview + repo/Beads search, update the current issue so it becomes actionable:
          - Prefer updating the issue `description` and/or `acceptance` with the intake brief output.
          - Example: `bd update wf-ba2.5.4.1 --description "<intake brief markdown>" --json`
          - Ensure the updated issue contains: problem, users, success criteria, constraints, related docs/issues, clarifying questions, and testable acceptance criteria.
    - Only resume `/implement` once the work item is clearly actionable.

2. Create a working branch

   - If you are already on a topic branch for this issue, or a parent of this issue, keep it.
   - Otherwise create a new branch named like `feature/wf-ba2.5.4.1-<short-suffix>` or `bug/wf-ba2.5.4.1-<short-suffix>`.
   - Do not commit directly on `main`.

3. Claim the issue

   - Run `bd update wf-ba2.5.4.1 --status in_progress --assignee "$USER" --json`.
   - If `--assignee` is not accepted in this environment, rerun without it.

4. Implement

   - Identify the smallest set of files to change.
   - Make the code changes.
   - If you discover additional required work, create new linked issues using `bd create ... --deps discovered-from:wf-ba2.5.4.1 --json`.
   - Author appropriate tests that validate the intended behaviour
   - Document the changes in the project documentation

5. Validate

   - Run the most specific checks available for the changed area (tests/lint/build).

6. Update the docs

   - If the issue has linked PRDs or design docs, update them with a summary of the work done, and references to imprtant files altered during the work.
   - Update the `docs/workflow.md` if the issue changes any part of the development workflow.
   - Update any relevant README.md files to reflect changes in usage, setup, or configuration.
   - Update any documents linked from `workflow.md` that are affected by the changes made in this issue.

7. Commit

   - Commit your code changes on the branch (include the Beads id in the commit message).
   - Ensure the commit message is clear and descriptive.

8. Update Beads (do not close)

   - Update the issue to include the PR URL using `--external-ref` and/or `--notes`.
   - Keep the issue in `in_progress` until the PR is merged.
   - Run `bd sync` before ending the session.
     - If there are no Beads changes to commit (or you are on an ephemeral branch without upstream), use `bd sync --flush-only`.
   - Output a summary of the goal of the issue and the work done, including a brief summary of changes to each file. Including a link to the PR. Provide hints on how to test any new functionality locally. Ask the user to review the PR and merge when ready.
   - Ask the producer to provide feedback on the implementation and, if ready to do so, to instruct the agent to "land the plane" (merge the PR and close the issue).

00001| ## Issue Tracking with bd (beads)
00002| 
00003| **IMPORTANT**: This project uses **bd (beads)** for ALL issue tracking. Do NOT use markdown TODOs, task lists, or other tracking methods.
00004| 
00005| ### Why bd?
00006| 
00007| - Dependency-aware: Track blockers and relationships between issues
00008| - Git-friendly: Auto-syncs to JSONL for version control
00009| - Agent-optimized: JSON output, ready work detection, discovered-from links
00010| - Prevents duplicate tracking systems and confusion
00011| 
00012| ### Quick Start
00013| 
00014| **Check for ready work:**
00015| 
00016| ```bash
00017| bd ready --json
00018| ```
00019| 
00020| **Create new issues:**
00021| 
00022| ```bash
00023| # For bugs and features, use templates for structured documentation
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json
00026| bd create "Epic title" --from-template epic -p 1 --json
00027| 
00028| # For quick tasks/chores, skip templates
00029| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json
00030| bd create "Chore title" -t chore -p 3 --json
00031| 
00032| # With dependencies or parent relationships
00033| bd create "Issue title" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:bd-123 --json
00034| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask (gets ID like epic-id.1)
00035| ```
00036| 
00037| **Claim and update:**
00038| 
00039| ```bash
00040| bd update bd-42 --status in_progress --json
00041| bd update bd-42 --priority 1 --json
00042| ```
00043| 
00044| **Complete work:**
00045| 
00046| ```bash
00047| bd close bd-42 --reason "Completed" --json
00048| ```
00049| 
00050| ### Issue Types
00051| 
00052| - `bug` - Something broken
00053| - `feature` - New functionality
00054| - `task` - Work item (tests, docs, refactoring)
00055| - `epic` - Large feature with subtasks
00056| - `chore` - Maintenance (dependencies, tooling)
00057| 
00058| ### Priorities
00059| 
00060| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00061| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00062| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00063| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00064| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00065| 
00066| ### Workflow for AI Agents
00067| 
00068| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready` shows unblocked issues
00069| 2. **Claim your task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00070| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00071| 4. **Discover new work?** Create linked issue:
00072|    - `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id>`
00073| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done"`
00074| 6. **Commit together**: Always commit the `.beads/issues.jsonl` file together with the code changes so issue state stays in sync with code state
00075| 
00076| ### Using bv as an AI sidecar
00077| 
00078| bv is a fast terminal UI for Beads projects (.beads/beads.jsonl). It renders lists/details and precomputes dependency metrics (PageRank, critical path, cycles, etc.) so you instantly see blockers and execution order. For agents, it’s a graph sidecar: instead of parsing JSONL or risking hallucinated traversal, call the robot flags to get deterministic, dependency-aware outputs.
00079| 
00080| _IMPORTANT: As an agent, you must ONLY use bv with the robot flags, otherwise you'll get stuck in the interactive TUI that's intended for human usage only!_
00081| 
00082| - bv --robot-help — shows all AI-facing commands.
00083| - bv --robot-insights — JSON graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, HITS, critical path, cycles) with top-N summaries for quick triage.
00084| - bv --robot-plan — JSON execution plan: parallel tracks, items per track, and unblocks lists showing what each item frees up.
00085| - bv --robot-priority — JSON priority recommendations with reasoning and confidence.
00086| - bv --robot-recipes — list recipes (default, actionable, blocked, etc.); apply via bv --recipe <name> to pre-filter/sort before other flags.
00087| - bv --robot-diff --diff-since <commit|date> — JSON diff of issue changes, new/closed items, and cycles introduced/resolved.
00088| 
00089| Use these commands instead of hand-rolling graph logic; bv already computes the hard parts so agents can act safely and quickly.
00090| 
00091| ### Auto-Sync
00092| 
00093| bd automatically syncs with git:
00094| 
00095| - Exports to `.beads/issues.jsonl` after changes (5s debounce)
00096| - Imports from JSONL when newer (e.g., after `git pull`)
00097| - No manual export/import needed!
00098| 
00099| ### GitHub Copilot Integration
00100| 
00101| If using GitHub Copilot, also create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for automatic instruction loading.
00102| Run `bd onboard` to get the content, or see step 2 of the onboard instructions.
00103| 
00104| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00105| 
00106| If using Claude or MCP-compatible clients, install the beads MCP server:
00107| 
00108| ```bash
00109| pip install beads-mcp
00110| ```
00111| 
00112| Add to MCP config (e.g., `~/.config/claude/config.json`):
00113| 
00114| ```json
00115| {
00116|   "beads": {
00117|     "command": "beads-mcp",
00118|     "args": []
00119|   }
00120| }
00121| ```
00122| 
00123| Then use `mcp__beads__*` functions instead of CLI commands.
00124| 
00125| ### Managing AI-Generated Planning Documents
00126| 
00127| AI assistants often create planning and design documents during development:
00128| 
00129| - PLAN.md, IMPLEMENTATION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md
00130| - DESIGN.md, CODEBASE_SUMMARY.md, INTEGRATION_PLAN.md
00131| - TESTING_GUIDE.md, TECHNICAL_DESIGN.md, and similar files
00132| 
00133| **Best Practice: Use a dedicated directory for these ephemeral files**
00134| 
00135| **Recommended approach:**
00136| 
00137| - Create a `history/` directory in the project root
00138| - Store ALL AI-generated planning/design docs in `history/`
00139| - Keep the repository root clean and focused on permanent project files
00140| - Only access `history/` when explicitly asked to review past planning
00141| 
00142| **Example .gitignore entry (optional):**
00143| 
00144| ```
00145| # AI planning documents (ephemeral)
00146| history/
00147| ```
00148| 
00149| **Benefits:**
00150| 
00151| - ✅ Clean repository root
00152| - ✅ Clear separation between ephemeral and permanent documentation
00153| - ✅ Easy to exclude from version control if desired
00154| - ✅ Preserves planning history for archeological research
00155| - ✅ Reduces noise when browsing the project
00156| 
00157| ### Templates
00158| 
00159| Beads provides structured templates for better documentation:
00160| 
00161| - **bug**: Includes steps to reproduce, expected/actual behavior, root cause analysis
00162| - **feature**: Includes motivation, use cases, technical design, alternatives considered
00163| - **epic**: Includes overview, success criteria, scope, architecture, dependencies
00164| 
00165| **When to use templates:**
00166| 
00167| - ✅ Use `--from-template bug` for all bug reports (better debugging context)
00168| - ✅ Use `--from-template feature` for new features (captures design decisions)
00169| - ✅ Use `--from-template epic` for large multi-issue projects
00170| - ❌ Skip templates for quick tasks/chores (unnecessary overhead)
00171| 
00172| **View templates:**
00173| 
00174| ```bash
00175| bd template list --json
00176| bd template show bug --json
00177| ```
00178| 
00179| ### CLI Help
00180| 
00181| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00182| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00183| 
00184| ### Important Rules
00185| 
00186| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00187| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00188| - ✅ Use templates (`--from-template`) for bugs, features, and epics
00189| - ✅ Link discovered work with `discovered-from` dependencies
00190| - ✅ Check `bd ready` before asking "what should I work on?"
00191| - ✅ Store AI planning docs in `history/` directory
00192| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00193| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00194| - ❌ Do NOT use external issue trackers
00195| - ❌ Do NOT duplicate tracking systems
00196| - ❌ Do NOT clutter repo root with planning documents
00197| 
00198| For more details, see README.md and QUICKSTART.md.
00199|
