00001| ## Issue Tracking with bd (beads)
00002| 
00003| **IMPORTANT**: This project uses **bd (beads)** for ALL issue tracking. Do NOT use markdown TODOs, task lists, or other tracking methods.
00004| 
00005| ### Why bd?
00006| 
00007| - Dependency-aware: Track blockers and relationships between issues
00008| - Git-friendly: Auto-syncs to JSONL for version control
00009| - Agent-optimized: JSON output, ready work detection, discovered-from links
00010| - Prevents duplicate tracking systems and confusion
00011| 
00012| ### Quick Start
00013| 
00014| **Check for ready work:**
00015| 
00016| ```bash
00017| bd ready --json
00018| ```
00019| 
00020| **Create new issues:**
00021| 
00022| ```bash
00023| # For bugs and features, use templates for structured documentation
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json
00026| bd create "Epic title" --from-template epic -p 1 --json
00027| 
00028| # For quick tasks/chores, skip templates
00029| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json
00030| bd create "Chore title" -t chore -p 3 --json
00031| 
00032| # With dependencies or parent relationships
00033| bd create "Issue title" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:bd-123 --json
00034| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask (gets ID like epic-id.1)
00035| ```
00036| 
00037| **Claim and update:**
00038| 
00039| ```bash
00040| bd update bd-42 --status in_progress --json
00041| bd update bd-42 --priority 1 --json
00042| ```
00043| 
00044| **Complete work:**
00045| 
00046| ```bash
00047| bd close bd-42 --reason "Completed" --json
00048| ```
00049| 
00050| ### Issue Types
00051| 
00052| - `bug` - Something broken
00053| - `feature` - New functionality
00054| - `task` - Work item (tests, docs, refactoring)
00055| - `epic` - Large feature with subtasks
00056| - `chore` - Maintenance (dependencies, tooling)
00057| 
00058| ### Priorities
00059| 
00060| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00061| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00062| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00063| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00064| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00065| 
00066| ### Workflow for AI Agents
00067| 
00068| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready` shows unblocked issues
00069| 2. **Claim your task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00070| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00071| 4. **Discover new work?** Create linked issue:
00072|    - `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id>`
00073| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done"`
00074| 6. **Commit together**: Always commit the `.beads/issues.jsonl` file together with the code changes so issue state stays in sync with code state
00075| 
00076| ### Using bv as an AI sidecar
00077| 
00078| bv is a fast terminal UI for Beads projects (.beads/beads.jsonl). It renders lists/details and precomputes dependency metrics (PageRank, critical path, cycles, etc.) so you instantly see blockers and execution order. For agents, it’s a graph sidecar: instead of parsing JSONL or risking hallucinated traversal, call the robot flags to get deterministic, dependency-aware outputs.
00079| 
00080| _IMPORTANT: As an agent, you must ONLY use bv with the robot flags, otherwise you'll get stuck in the interactive TUI that's intended for human usage only!_
00081| 
00082| - bv --robot-help — shows all AI-facing commands.
00083| - bv --robot-insights — JSON graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, HITS, critical path, cycles) with top-N summaries for quick triage.
00084| - bv --robot-plan — JSON execution plan: parallel tracks, items per track, and unblocks lists showing what each item frees up.
00085| - bv --robot-priority — JSON priority recommendations with reasoning and confidence.
00086| - bv --robot-recipes — list recipes (default, actionable, blocked, etc.); apply via bv --recipe <name> to pre-filter/sort before other flags.
00087| - bv --robot-diff --diff-since <commit|date> — JSON diff of issue changes, new/closed items, and cycles introduced/resolved.
00088| 
00089| Use these commands instead of hand-rolling graph logic; bv already computes the hard parts so agents can act safely and quickly.
00090| 
00091| ### Auto-Sync
00092| 
00093| bd automatically syncs with git:
00094| 
00095| - Exports to `.beads/issues.jsonl` after changes (5s debounce)
00096| - Imports from JSONL when newer (e.g., after `git pull`)
00097| - No manual export/import needed!
00098| 
00099| ### GitHub Copilot Integration
00100| 
00101| If using GitHub Copilot, also create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for automatic instruction loading.
00102| Run `bd onboard` to get the content, or see step 2 of the onboard instructions.
00103| 
00104| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00105| 
00106| If using Claude or MCP-compatible clients, install the beads MCP server:
00107| 
00108| ```bash
00109| pip install beads-mcp
00110| ```
00111| 
00112| Add to MCP config (e.g., `~/.config/claude/config.json`):
00113| 
00114| ```json
00115| {
00116|   "beads": {
00117|     "command": "beads-mcp",
00118|     "args": []
00119|   }
00120| }
00121| ```
00122| 
00123| Then use `mcp__beads__*` functions instead of CLI commands.
00124| 
00125| ### Managing AI-Generated Planning Documents
00126| 
00127| AI assistants often create planning and design documents during development:
00128| 
00129| - PLAN.md, IMPLEMENTATION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md
00130| - DESIGN.md, CODEBASE_SUMMARY.md, INTEGRATION_PLAN.md
00131| - TESTING_GUIDE.md, TECHNICAL_DESIGN.md, and similar files
00132| 
00133| **Best Practice: Use a dedicated directory for these ephemeral files**
00134| 
00135| **Recommended approach:**
00136| 
00137| - Create a `history/` directory in the project root
00138| - Store ALL AI-generated planning/design docs in `history/`
00139| - Keep the repository root clean and focused on permanent project files
00140| - Only access `history/` when explicitly asked to review past planning
00141| 
00142| **Example .gitignore entry (optional):**
00143| 
00144| ```
00145| # AI planning documents (ephemeral)
00146| history/
00147| ```
00148| 
00149| **Benefits:**
00150| 
00151| - ✅ Clean repository root
00152| - ✅ Clear separation between ephemeral and permanent documentation
00153| - ✅ Easy to exclude from version control if desired
00154| - ✅ Preserves planning history for archeological research
00155| - ✅ Reduces noise when browsing the project
00156| 
00157| ### Templates
00158| 
00159| Beads provides structured templates for better documentation:
00160| 
00161| - **bug**: Includes steps to reproduce, expected/actual behavior, root cause analysis
00162| - **feature**: Includes motivation, use cases, technical design, alternatives considered
00163| - **epic**: Includes overview, success criteria, scope, architecture, dependencies
00164| 
00165| **When to use templates:**
00166| 
00167| - ✅ Use `--from-template bug` for all bug reports (better debugging context)
00168| - ✅ Use `--from-template feature` for new features (captures design decisions)
00169| - ✅ Use `--from-template epic` for large multi-issue projects
00170| - ❌ Skip templates for quick tasks/chores (unnecessary overhead)
00171| 
00172| **View templates:**
00173| 
00174| ```bash
00175| bd template list --json
00176| bd template show bug --json
00177| ```
00178| 
00179| ### CLI Help
00180| 
00181| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00182| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00183| 
00184| ### Important Rules
00185| 
00186| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00187| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00188| - ✅ Use templates (`--from-template`) for bugs, features, and epics
00189| - ✅ Link discovered work with `discovered-from` dependencies
00190| - ✅ Check `bd ready` before asking "what should I work on?"
00191| - ✅ Store AI planning docs in `history/` directory
00192| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00193| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00194| - ❌ Do NOT use external issue trackers
00195| - ❌ Do NOT duplicate tracking systems
00196| - ❌ Do NOT clutter repo root with planning documents
00197| 
00198| For more details, see README.md and QUICKSTART.md.
00199| 
00200| <!-- bv-agent-instructions-v1 -->
00201| 
00202| ---
00203| 
00204| ## Beads Workflow Integration
00205| 
00206| This project uses [beads_viewer](https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer) for issue tracking. Issues are stored in `.beads/` and tracked in git.
00207| 
00208| ### Essential Commands
00209| 
00210| ```bash
00211| # View issues (launches TUI - avoid in automated sessions)
00212| bv
00213| 
00214| # CLI commands for agents (use these instead)
00215| bd ready              # Show issues ready to work (no blockers)
00216| bd list --status=open # All open issues
00217| bd show <id>          # Full issue details with dependencies
00218| bd create --title="..." --type=task --priority=2
00219| bd update <id> --status=in_progress
00220| bd close <id> --reason="Completed"
00221| bd close <id1> <id2>  # Close multiple issues at once
00222| bd sync               # Commit and push changes
00223| ```
00224| 
00225| ### Workflow Pattern
00226| 
00227| 1. **Start**: Run `bd ready` to find actionable work
00228| 2. **Claim**: Use `bd update <id> --status=in_progress`
00229| 3. **Work**: Implement the task on a branch named with the bd id (see naming conventions)
00230| 4. **Complete**: Use `bd close <id>`
00231| 5. **Sync**: Always run `bd sync` at session end
00232| 
00233| Branch guidance (branch-per-bd):
00234| 
00235| - All work MUST be performed on branches that include the bd id. Create a short-lived topic branch from `origin/main` for each bd issue.
00236| - If a branch already exists for the bd issue, reuse it and record your involvement in bd comments.
00237| - Agents and humans should avoid editing files that other agents have claimed in bd unless coordination is documented.
00238| 
00239| ### Key Concepts
00240| 
00241| - **Dependencies**: Issues can block other issues. `bd ready` shows only unblocked work.
00242| - **Priority**: P0=critical, P1=high, P2=medium, P3=low, P4=backlog (use numbers, not words)
00243| - **Types**: task, bug, feature, epic, question, docs
00244| - **Blocking**: `bd dep add <issue> <depends-on>` to add dependencies
00245| 
00246| ### Session Protocol
00247| 
00248| **Before ending any session, run this checklist:**
00249| 
00250| ```bash
00251| git status              # Check what changed
00252| git add <files>         # Stage code changes
00253| bd sync                 # Commit beads changes
00254| git commit -m "..."     # Commit code
00255| bd sync                 # Commit any new beads changes
00256| git push                # Push to remote
00257| ```
00258| 
00259| ### Best Practices
00260| 
00261| - Check `bd ready` at session start to find available work
00262| - Update status as you work (in_progress → closed)
00263| - Create new issues with `bd create` when you discover tasks
00264| - Use descriptive titles and set appropriate priority/type
00265| - Always `bd sync` before ending session
00266| 
00267| <!-- end-bv-agent-instructions -->
00268| 
00269| ## Landing the Plane (Session Completion)
00270| 
00271| **When ending a work session**, you MUST complete ALL steps below. Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds.
00272| 
00273| **MANDATORY WORKFLOW:**
00274| 
00275| 1. **File issues for remaining work** - Create issues for anything that needs follow-up
00276| 2. **Run quality gates** (if code changed) - Tests, linters, builds, stop the landing if a test fails
00277| 3. **Document changes** - Update docs, changelogs, comments
00278| 4. **PUSH TO REMOTE** - This is MANDATORY:
00279|    ```bash
00280|    git pull --rebase
00281|    bd sync
00282|    git push
00283|    git status  # MUST show "up to date with origin"
00284|    ```
00285| 5. **Raise a PR** (if applicable, ask if unsure) - Link to issues and update the BD with a link to the PR.
00286| 6. Notify the producer that the PR is ready for review. Stop this process until the PR is reviewed and merged. Once reviewed and merged, proceed.
00287| 7. **Update issue status** - Close finished work, update in-progress items
00288| 8. **Clean up** - Clear stashes, prune remote branches
00289| 9. **Verify** - All changes committed AND pushed
00290| 10. **Hand off** - Provide context for next session
00291| **CRITICAL RULES:**
00292| 
00293| - Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds
00294| - NEVER stop before pushing - that leaves work stranded locally
00295| - NEVER say "ready to push when you are" - YOU must push
00296| - If push fails, resolve and retry until it succeeds
00297| - When using backticks in strings that are to be passed as arguments to shell commands (e.g. waif, gh), escape them properly to avoid errors
00298| 
00299| ## Project structure
00300| 
00301| - Source code lives in `src/`
00302| - Tests live in `tests/`
00303| - Documentation lives in `docs/`
00304| - AI-generated planning docs go in `history/` (ephemeral)
00305| - Beads configs live in `.beads/`
00306| - Beads issues live in `.beads/issues.jsonl`
00307| - OpenCode configs live in `.opencode`
00308| - OpenCode agent commands live in `.opencode/command/` - these are not related to the WAFI CLI itself
00309| 

(End of file - total 309 lines)
</file>

00001| # GitHub Copilot Instructions
00002| 
00003| ## Issue Tracking with bd
00004| 
00005| This project uses **bd (beads)** for issue tracking - a Git-backed tracker designed for AI-supervised coding workflows.
00006| 
00007| **Key Features:**
00008| - Dependency-aware issue tracking
00009| - Auto-sync with Git via JSONL
00010| - AI-optimized CLI with JSON output
00011| - Built-in daemon for background operations
00012| - MCP server integration for Claude and other AI assistants
00013|

00015| 
00016| ### Essential Commands
00017| 
00018| ```bash
00019| # Find work
00020| bd ready --json                    # Unblocked issues
00021| bd stale --days 30 --json          # Forgotten issues
00022| 
00023| # Create and manage
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json  # Use template for bugs
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json  # Use template for features
00026| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json  # Skip template for tasks
00027| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask
00028| bd update <id> --status in_progress --json
00029| bd close <id> --reason "Done" --json
00030| 
00031| # Search
00032| bd list --status open --priority 1 --json
00033| bd show <id> --json
00034| 
00035| # Sync (CRITICAL at end of session!)
00036| bd sync  # Force immediate export/commit/push
00037| ```
00038| 
00039| ### Workflow
00040| 
00041| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready --json`
00042| 2. **Claim task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00043| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document

00045| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done" --json`
00046| 6. **Sync**: `bd sync` (flushes changes to git immediately)
00047| 
00048| ### Priorities
00049| 
00050| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00051| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00052| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00053| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00054| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00055| 
00056| ### Git Workflow
00057|

00062| ### MCP Server (Recommended)

You are implementing a Beads issue in this repository.

Argument handling:

- The user should run this as `/implement <bd-id>`.
- Use `wf-ba2.5.4.3` as the Beads ID.

Project rules (must follow):

- Use `bd` for ALL task tracking; do not create markdown TODOs.
- Keep changes minimal and scoped to the issue.
- Validate changes with the most relevant tests/commands available.
- Use a git branch + PR workflow (no direct-to-main changes).
- Ensure the working branch is pushed to `origin` before you finish.
- Do NOT close the Beads issue until the PR is merged.

Context files:

- Tracker workflow: @AGENTS.md
- Copilot rules: @.github/copilot-instructions.md

the PM indirectly benefits via faster/safer agent execution.\n\nSuccess criteria\n- `waif context` (alias: `waif ctx`) generates/updates a single agent-oriented “signpost” document: `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md`.\n- The context pack provides “minimum efficient” discovery:\n  - Links to all important docs (PRDs/specs, user docs, workflow rules, issue tracking rules, agent roles, key source folders).\n  - Each entry includes a short description (1–2 bullets) describing what it contains and when to read it.\n  - Large docs may be referenced multiple times, pointing at specific sections.\n- The pack avoids rapidly-changing content; Process:

0. Safety gate: handle dirty working tree

   - Before making any changes, check whether the working tree is clean (`git status --porcelain=v1 -b`).
   - If there are _any_ uncommitted changes (modified, staged, or untracked files), **stop and ask the user what to do**. Do not assume changes are irrelevant.
   - Offer clear options and wait for an explicit choice:
     - A) Carry changes into this issue branch (continue as-is).
     - B) Commit current changes first (either on current branch or a separate "prep" branch).
     - C) Stash changes (and confirm whether to pop later).
     - D) Revert/discard changes (only with explicit confirmation).
     - E) Abort implementation so the user can inspect.

1. Understand the issue

   - Restate the acceptance criteria and constraints from the issue JSON.
   - Identify dependencies/blockers; if blocked, explain what is missing and ask the user how to proceed.
   - Review the issue `description`, `notes`, and any `comments` for references to PRDs, implementation plans, or other linked docs; if present, open and read those sources before proceeding.

1.1 Definition gate (must do before implementation)

    Before writing any code, confirm the Beads issue is sufficiently well-defined to implement.

    Minimum definition checklist:

    - Clear scope: what is in-scope vs out-of-scope
    - Concrete acceptance criteria (testable, not just aspirational)
    - Constraints/compatibility expectations (if any)
    - Obvious unknowns captured as questions (or resolved)

    If the issue is not sufficiently defined:

    - Stop implementation.
    - Work through the **intake brief interview** first to fully define the work.
       - Use `.opencode/command/intake.md` as the guide for the questions and searches.
       - IMPORTANT: when intake is performed as part of `/implement`, it must **always update the existing issue `wf-ba2.5.4.3`**. Do **not** create a new Beads issue.
       - After the intake interview + repo/Beads search, update the current issue so it becomes actionable:
          - Prefer updating the issue `description` and/or `acceptance` with the intake brief output.
          - Example: `bd update wf-ba2.5.4.3 --description "<intake brief markdown>" --json`
          - Ensure the updated issue contains: problem, users, success criteria, constraints, related docs/issues, clarifying questions, and testable acceptance criteria.
    - Only resume `/implement` once the work item is clearly actionable.

2. Create a working branch

   - If you are already on a topic branch for this issue, or a parent of this issue, keep it.
   - Otherwise create a new branch named like `feature/wf-ba2.5.4.3-<short-suffix>` or `bug/wf-ba2.5.4.3-<short-suffix>`.
   - Do not commit directly on `main`.

3. Claim the issue

   - Run `bd update wf-ba2.5.4.3 --status in_progress --assignee "$USER" --json`.
   - If `--assignee` is not accepted in this environment, rerun without it.

4. Implement

   - Identify the smallest set of files to change.
   - Make the code changes.
   - If you discover additional required work, create new linked issues using `bd create ... --deps discovered-from:wf-ba2.5.4.3 --json`.
   - Author appropriate tests that validate the intended behaviour
   - Document the changes in the project documentation

5. Validate

   - Run the most specific checks available for the changed area (tests/lint/build).

6. Update the docs

   - If the issue has linked PRDs or design docs, update them with a summary of the work done, and references to imprtant files altered during the work.
   - Update the `docs/workflow.md` if the issue changes any part of the development workflow.
   - Update any relevant README.md files to reflect changes in usage, setup, or configuration.
   - Update any documents linked from `workflow.md` that are affected by the changes made in this issue.

7. Commit

   - Commit your code changes on the branch (include the Beads id in the commit message).
   - Ensure the commit message is clear and descriptive.

8. Update Beads (do not close)

   - Update the issue to include the PR URL using `--external-ref` and/or `--notes`.
   - Keep the issue in `in_progress` until the PR is merged.
   - Run `bd sync` before ending the session.
     - If there are no Beads changes to commit (or you are on an ephemeral branch without upstream), use `bd sync --flush-only`.
   - Output a summary of the goal of the issue and the work done, including a brief summary of changes to each file. Including a link to the PR. Provide hints on how to test any new functionality locally. Ask the user to review the PR and merge when ready.
   - Ask the producer to provide feedback on the implementation and, if ready to do so, to instruct the agent to "land the plane" (merge the PR and close the issue).

00001| ## Issue Tracking with bd (beads)
00002| 
00003| **IMPORTANT**: This project uses **bd (beads)** for ALL issue tracking. Do NOT use markdown TODOs, task lists, or other tracking methods.
00004| 
00005| ### Why bd?
00006| 
00007| - Dependency-aware: Track blockers and relationships between issues
00008| - Git-friendly: Auto-syncs to JSONL for version control
00009| - Agent-optimized: JSON output, ready work detection, discovered-from links
00010| - Prevents duplicate tracking systems and confusion
00011| 
00012| ### Quick Start
00013| 
00014| **Check for ready work:**
00015| 
00016| ```bash
00017| bd ready --json
00018| ```
00019| 
00020| **Create new issues:**
00021| 
00022| ```bash
00023| # For bugs and features, use templates for structured documentation
00024| bd create "Bug title" --from-template bug -p 1 --json
00025| bd create "Feature title" --from-template feature -p 2 --json
00026| bd create "Epic title" --from-template epic -p 1 --json
00027| 
00028| # For quick tasks/chores, skip templates
00029| bd create "Task title" -t task -p 2 --json
00030| bd create "Chore title" -t chore -p 3 --json
00031| 
00032| # With dependencies or parent relationships
00033| bd create "Issue title" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:bd-123 --json
00034| bd create "Subtask" --parent <epic-id> --json  # Hierarchical subtask (gets ID like epic-id.1)
00035| ```
00036| 
00037| **Claim and update:**
00038| 
00039| ```bash
00040| bd update bd-42 --status in_progress --json
00041| bd update bd-42 --priority 1 --json
00042| ```
00043| 
00044| **Complete work:**
00045| 
00046| ```bash
00047| bd close bd-42 --reason "Completed" --json
00048| ```
00049| 
00050| ### Issue Types
00051| 
00052| - `bug` - Something broken
00053| - `feature` - New functionality
00054| - `task` - Work item (tests, docs, refactoring)
00055| - `epic` - Large feature with subtasks
00056| - `chore` - Maintenance (dependencies, tooling)
00057| 
00058| ### Priorities
00059| 
00060| - `0` - Critical (security, data loss, broken builds)
00061| - `1` - High (major features, important bugs)
00062| - `2` - Medium (default, nice-to-have)
00063| - `3` - Low (polish, optimization)
00064| - `4` - Backlog (future ideas)
00065| 
00066| ### Workflow for AI Agents
00067| 
00068| 1. **Check ready work**: `bd ready` shows unblocked issues
00069| 2. **Claim your task**: `bd update <id> --status in_progress`
00070| 3. **Work on it**: Implement, test, document
00071| 4. **Discover new work?** Create linked issue:
00072|    - `bd create "Found bug" -p 1 --deps discovered-from:<parent-id>`
00073| 5. **Complete**: `bd close <id> --reason "Done"`
00074| 6. **Commit together**: Always commit the `.beads/issues.jsonl` file together with the code changes so issue state stays in sync with code state
00075| 
00076| ### Using bv as an AI sidecar
00077| 
00078| bv is a fast terminal UI for Beads projects (.beads/beads.jsonl). It renders lists/details and precomputes dependency metrics (PageRank, critical path, cycles, etc.) so you instantly see blockers and execution order. For agents, it’s a graph sidecar: instead of parsing JSONL or risking hallucinated traversal, call the robot flags to get deterministic, dependency-aware outputs.
00079| 
00080| _IMPORTANT: As an agent, you must ONLY use bv with the robot flags, otherwise you'll get stuck in the interactive TUI that's intended for human usage only!_
00081| 
00082| - bv --robot-help — shows all AI-facing commands.
00083| - bv --robot-insights — JSON graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, HITS, critical path, cycles) with top-N summaries for quick triage.
00084| - bv --robot-plan — JSON execution plan: parallel tracks, items per track, and unblocks lists showing what each item frees up.
00085| - bv --robot-priority — JSON priority recommendations with reasoning and confidence.
00086| - bv --robot-recipes — list recipes (default, actionable, blocked, etc.); apply via bv --recipe <name> to pre-filter/sort before other flags.
00087| - bv --robot-diff --diff-since <commit|date> — JSON diff of issue changes, new/closed items, and cycles introduced/resolved.
00088| 
00089| Use these commands instead of hand-rolling graph logic; bv already computes the hard parts so agents can act safely and quickly.
00090| 
00091| ### Auto-Sync
00092| 
00093| bd automatically syncs with git:
00094| 
00095| - Exports to `.beads/issues.jsonl` after changes (5s debounce)
00096| - Imports from JSONL when newer (e.g., after `git pull`)
00097| - No manual export/import needed!
00098| 
00099| ### GitHub Copilot Integration
00100| 
00101| If using GitHub Copilot, also create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for automatic instruction loading.
00102| Run `bd onboard` to get the content, or see step 2 of the onboard instructions.
00103| 
00104| ### MCP Server (Recommended)
00105| 
00106| If using Claude or MCP-compatible clients, install the beads MCP server:
00107| 
00108| ```bash
00109| pip install beads-mcp
00110| ```
00111| 
00112| Add to MCP config (e.g., `~/.config/claude/config.json`):
00113| 
00114| ```json
00115| {
00116|   "beads": {
00117|     "command": "beads-mcp",
00118|     "args": []
00119|   }
00120| }
00121| ```
00122| 
00123| Then use `mcp__beads__*` functions instead of CLI commands.
00124| 
00125| ### Managing AI-Generated Planning Documents
00126| 
00127| AI assistants often create planning and design documents during development:
00128| 
00129| - PLAN.md, IMPLEMENTATION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md
00130| - DESIGN.md, CODEBASE_SUMMARY.md, INTEGRATION_PLAN.md
00131| - TESTING_GUIDE.md, TECHNICAL_DESIGN.md, and similar files
00132| 
00133| **Best Practice: Use a dedicated directory for these ephemeral files**
00134| 
00135| **Recommended approach:**
00136| 
00137| - Create a `history/` directory in the project root
00138| - Store ALL AI-generated planning/design docs in `history/`
00139| - Keep the repository root clean and focused on permanent project files
00140| - Only access `history/` when explicitly asked to review past planning
00141| 
00142| **Example .gitignore entry (optional):**
00143| 
00144| ```
00145| # AI planning documents (ephemeral)
00146| history/
00147| ```
00148| 
00149| **Benefits:**
00150| 
00151| - ✅ Clean repository root
00152| - ✅ Clear separation between ephemeral and permanent documentation
00153| - ✅ Easy to exclude from version control if desired
00154| - ✅ Preserves planning history for archeological research
00155| - ✅ Reduces noise when browsing the project
00156| 
00157| ### Templates
00158| 
00159| Beads provides structured templates for better documentation:
00160| 
00161| - **bug**: Includes steps to reproduce, expected/actual behavior, root cause analysis
00162| - **feature**: Includes motivation, use cases, technical design, alternatives considered
00163| - **epic**: Includes overview, success criteria, scope, architecture, dependencies
00164| 
00165| **When to use templates:**
00166| 
00167| - ✅ Use `--from-template bug` for all bug reports (better debugging context)
00168| - ✅ Use `--from-template feature` for new features (captures design decisions)
00169| - ✅ Use `--from-template epic` for large multi-issue projects
00170| - ❌ Skip templates for quick tasks/chores (unnecessary overhead)
00171| 
00172| **View templates:**
00173| 
00174| ```bash
00175| bd template list --json
00176| bd template show bug --json
00177| ```
00178| 
00179| ### CLI Help
00180| 
00181| Run `bd <command> --help` to see all available flags for any command.
00182| For example: `bd create --help` shows `--parent`, `--deps`, `--assignee`, etc.
00183| 
00184| ### Important Rules
00185| 
00186| - ✅ Use bd for ALL task tracking
00187| - ✅ Always use `--json` flag for programmatic use
00188| - ✅ Use templates (`--from-template`) for bugs, features, and epics
00189| - ✅ Link discovered work with `discovered-from` dependencies
00190| - ✅ Check `bd ready` before asking "what should I work on?"
00191| - ✅ Store AI planning docs in `history/` directory
00192| - ✅ Run `bd <cmd> --help` to discover available flags
00193| - ❌ Do NOT create markdown TODO lists
00194| - ❌ Do NOT use external issue trackers
00195| - ❌ Do NOT duplicate tracking systems
00196| - ❌ Do NOT clutter repo root with planning documents
00197| 
00198| For more details, see README.md and QUICKSTART.md.
00199| 
00200| <!-- bv-agent-instructions-v1 -->
00201| 
00202| ---
00203| 
00204| ## Beads Workflow Integration
00205| 
00206| This project uses [beads_viewer](https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer) for issue tracking. Issues are stored in `.beads/` and tracked in git.
00207| 
00208| ### Essential Commands
00209| 
00210| ```bash
00211| # View issues (launches TUI - avoid in automated sessions)
00212| bv
00213| 
00214| # CLI commands for agents (use these instead)
00215| bd ready              # Show issues ready to work (no blockers)
00216| bd list --status=open # All open issues
00217| bd show <id>          # Full issue details with dependencies
00218| bd create --title="..." --type=task --priority=2
00219| bd update <id> --status=in_progress
00220| bd close <id> --reason="Completed"
00221| bd close <id1> <id2>  # Close multiple issues at once
00222| bd sync               # Commit and push changes
00223| ```
00224| 
00225| ### Workflow Pattern
00226| 
00227| 1. **Start**: Run `bd ready` to find actionable work
00228| 2. **Claim**: Use `bd update <id> --status=in_progress`
00229| 3. **Work**: Implement the task on a branch named with the bd id (see naming conventions)
00230| 4. **Complete**: Use `bd close <id>`
00231| 5. **Sync**: Always run `bd sync` at session end
00232| 
00233| Branch guidance (branch-per-bd):
00234| 
00235| - All work MUST be performed on branches that include the bd id. Create a short-lived topic branch from `origin/main` for each bd issue.
00236| - If a branch already exists for the bd issue, reuse it and record your involvement in bd comments.
00237| - Agents and humans should avoid editing files that other agents have claimed in bd unless coordination is documented.
00238| 
00239| ### Key Concepts
00240| 
00241| - **Dependencies**: Issues can block other issues. `bd ready` shows only unblocked work.
00242| - **Priority**: P0=critical, P1=high, P2=medium, P3=low, P4=backlog (use numbers, not words)
00243| - **Types**: task, bug, feature, epic, question, docs
00244| - **Blocking**: `bd dep add <issue> <depends-on>` to add dependencies
00245| 
00246| ### Session Protocol
00247| 
00248| **Before ending any session, run this checklist:**
00249| 
00250| ```bash
00251| git status              # Check what changed
00252| git add <files>         # Stage code changes
00253| bd sync                 # Commit beads changes
00254| git commit -m "..."     # Commit code
00255| bd sync                 # Commit any new beads changes
00256| git push                # Push to remote
00257| ```
00258| 
00259| ### Best Practices
00260| 
00261| - Check `bd ready` at session start to find available work
00262| - Update status as you work (in_progress → closed)
00263| - Create new issues with `bd create` when you discover tasks
00264| - Use descriptive titles and set appropriate priority/type
00265| - Always `bd sync` before ending session
00266| 
00267| <!-- end-bv-agent-instructions -->
00268| 
00269| ## Landing the Plane (Session Completion)
00270| 
00271| **When ending a work session**, you MUST complete ALL steps below. Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds.
00272| 
00273| **MANDATORY WORKFLOW:**
00274| 
00275| 1. **File issues for remaining work** - Create issues for anything that needs follow-up
00276| 2. **Run quality gates** (if code changed) - Tests, linters, builds, stop the landing if a test fails
00277| 3. **Document changes** - Update docs, changelogs, comments
00278| 4. **PUSH TO REMOTE** - This is MANDATORY:
00279|    ```bash
00280|    git pull --rebase
00281|    bd sync
00282|    git push
00283|    git status  # MUST show "up to date with origin"
00284|    ```
00285| 5. **Raise a PR** (if applicable, ask if unsure) - Link to issues and update the BD with a link to the PR.
00286| 6. Notify the producer that the PR is ready for review. Stop this process until the PR is reviewed and merged. Once reviewed and merged, proceed.
00287| 7. **Update issue status** - Close finished work, update in-progress items
00288| 8. **Clean up** - Clear stashes, prune remote branches
00289| 9. **Verify** - All changes committed AND pushed
00290| 10. **Hand off** - Provide context for next session
00291| **CRITICAL RULES:**
00292| 
00293| - Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds
00294| - NEVER stop before pushing - that leaves work stranded locally
00295| - NEVER say "ready to push when you are" - YOU must push
00296| - If push fails, resolve and retry until it succeeds
00297| - When using backticks in strings that are to be passed as arguments to shell commands (e.g. waif, gh), escape them properly to avoid errors
00298| 
00299| ## Project structure
00300| 
00301| - Source code lives in `src/`
00302| - Tests live in `tests/`
00303| - Documentation lives in `docs/`
00304| - AI-generated planning docs go in `history/` (ephemeral)
00305| - Beads configs live in `.beads/`
00306| - Beads issues live in `.beads/issues.jsonl`
00307| - OpenCode configs live in `.opencode`
00308| - OpenCode agent commands live in `.opencode/command/` - these are not related to the WAFI CLI itself
00309|

parts.text:
Context:
- PR: https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/90 (branch bd-wf-ba2.3.4/implement-integrate-context)
- Beads issue: wf-ba2.3.4 (currently in_progress)
- Files involved: .beads/issues.jsonl, .opencode/command/prd.md, docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md

Task: safely 'land the plane' for wf-ba2.3.4. Perform these steps and return a single JSON object with fields: { merged: boolean, merge_commit: <sha>|null, pr_url, bd_comment_id, bd_close_result, notes }.

Steps to perform (must follow exactly):
1) Validate that PR #90 is mergeable and that CI checks have passed. Use 'gh pr view 90 --json mergeState,mergeable,commits,headRefName,baseRefName,checks' or equivalent. If checks have not passed or PR is not mergeable, stop and return merged:false with diagnostics in notes. DO NOT force-merge or bypass failing checks.

2) If mergeable and checks passed, merge the PR using GitHub CLI: 'gh pr merge 90 --merge --body "Merge PR #90: land wf-ba2.3.4 per user request (Map)"'. Do NOT delete the branch. Capture the resulting merge commit sha.

3) After successful merge, post a bd comment on wf-ba2.3.4 documenting the landing with content similar to:
"Map: PR merged and issue landed.\n\nPR: https://github.com/SorraTheOrc/waif/pull/90\nMerge commit: <sha>\nFiles landed:\n- .beads/issues.jsonl\n- .opencode/command/prd.md\n- docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md\n\nNotes: branch bd-wf-ba2.3.4/implement-integrate-context was NOT deleted."
Use 'bd comment wf-ba2.3.4 "..." --json' and capture the comment id.

4) Close the beads issue: 'bd close wf-ba2.3.4 --reason "Completed: PR #90 merged" --json'. Capture result.

5) Run 'bd sync' to persist changes.

6) Return the JSON object described above.

Safety constraints:
- DO NOT delete branches or run destructive git commands (reset, rebase interactive, push --force).
- DO NOT bypass failing CI checks.
- If any step fails, return merged:false and include command outputs in notes.

Run commands in the repository root. Return only the JSON object as the final response from the agent.

  - a NEW PRD, or
  - an UPDATE to an existing PRD.
- Create a Beads issue to track the intake brief.
- Record all gathered information in the issue description.

Hard requirements:

- Use an **interview style**.
- Ask concise, high-signal questions.
- Soft-maximum of **three questions per iteration**.
- Do not invent requirements or constraints; if unknown, ask.
- Search the repo for related PRDs/specs and surface likely duplicates.
- Search Beads for related issues.
- Produce a short list of clarifying questions.
- Create a Beads issue to track the brief.

Argument handling:

- The user may optionally provide a short topic/title as `The opencode plugin should provide a mechanism for agents to get context specific to a given issue ID. This will be used when starting work on an item to help inform the agents work.`.
  - If provided, treat it as a working title for the intake brief.
  - Do not attempt to parse flags/options.
- If `The opencode plugin should provide a mechanism for agents to get context specific to a given issue ID. This will be used when starting work on an item to help inform the agents work.` is empty, ask the user for a short working title.

Process (must follow):


1. Interview (human-provided content)

   In multiple iterations (≤ 3 questions each), gather the following information (providing suggestions/examples informed by relevant context
   sources where helpful):

   - Problem (one paragraph)
     - What is the problem / opportunity?
     - Who experiences it (user personas)?
   - Success criteria (one paragraph)
     - What outcomes define success?
     - If possible, include a measurable target or a clear “done” test.
   - Constraints (one paragraph)
     - Compatibility expectations (what must not break)

   If the user indicates this is a change to something existing, also gather:

   - What exists today (current behavior)
   - What should change (desired behavior)
   - Where it likely lives (paths, commands, APIs)

2. Repo search (agent responsibility)

   Use the user’s answers to derive 2–6 keywords. Then search for related artifacts.

   - Search `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md` if present, Otherwise, scan `docs/`, `README.md`, and other high-level files for relevant context about the product/repo.
     - Use ripgrep where available (where not available use an alternative, but ask the user to install ripgrep).
     - Examples:
       - `rg -n "Product Requirements Document|\bPRD\b" docs/`
       - `rg -n "<keyword1>|<keyword2>" docs/ src/ README.md`
   - Search for related Beads issues covering this topic (duplicates / precursors):
     - Examples:
       - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
       - `bd ready --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, use a best-effort alternative and ask the user to install ripgrep.
     - If you find candidates:
       - List them as "Related issues" (ids + titles).
       - If one clearly already represents this work, prefer updating that issue (or creating a child issue) instead of creating a duplicate.
   - If you find candidates:
     - List them as "Likely duplicates / related docs".
     - Ask the user to confirm whether to update one of them.

3. Beads search (agent responsibility)

   Search existing issues for overlaps.

   - Use Beads as the source of truth.
   - Suggested approaches (pick the simplest available in the environment):
     - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, ask the user whether you should do a broad manual scan (and suggest the user installs ripgrep).

   Output:

   - "Related issues" list (ids + titles) OR explicitly state "No obvious related issues found".

4. Clarifying questions (agent responsibility)

   Produce a short list (0–7) of clarifying questions that would unblock PRD creation/editing.
   Keep them actionable and specific.

5. Decide next step: NEW PRD vs UPDATE

   Decide, then confirm with the user:

   - If UPDATE: identify the file path to update (ask for confirmation if uncertain).
   - If NEW: propose a PRD file path under `docs/dev/`.
     - Convention: `docs/dev/<feature>_PRD.md`.

6. Feedback Gate

  Propose the description of the bead, priority level, parent, related isses etc.

  Ask the user if there are any clarifictions, changes or further research required before proceeding. Carry out any further instructtions before proceeding. 

  Only proceed to the next step if the user gives permission to do so.

7. Draft the intake brief (agent responsibility)

   Compile all gathered information into a well-structured intake brief in Markdown format.

   Use the following template:

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

8. Review 1 (agent responsibility)

  Complete the **first full draft** of this workflow artifact for the current work item.
  - Be creative and propose strong defaults.
  - If uncertain, present 2-3 alternatives and choose one, explaining why.
  - Keep it actionable: concrete lists, commands, checklists, and examples.
  - Assume the reader wants momentum; do not over-polish yet.

9. Review 2 (agent responsibilitY)

  Review the full draft for completeness, clarity, and actionability.
  - Ensure all required sections are present and well-structured.
  - Verify that all user-provided content is accurately captured.
  - Check for consistency in terminology and formatting.
  - Refine language for clarity and conciseness.
  - Ensure the proposed next steps are clear and actionable.

10. Review 3 (Agent responsibility)

  Audit the current artifact for correctness and real-world usability.
  - Add missing constraints, assumptions, and decision points.
  - Add edge cases, failure modes, and "what could go wrong" notes.
  - Ensure steps are testable/verifiable.
  - Remove anything not serving the artifact purpose.

11. Review 4 (Agent responsibility)

  Polish the artifact for clarity and fast reading.
  - Rewrite unclear sections and tighten wording.
  - Convert paragraphs into bullets/checklists where helpful.
  - Normalize terminology and naming.
  - Ensure examples/commands are copy-pastable and consistent.

12. Finak Review (Agent responsibility)

  Perform a final QA review of the artifact.
  - Check for internal consistency and contradictions.
  - Ensure it aligns with repo conventions and the Workflow doc.
  - Ensure every requirement is actionable and measurable.
  - Emit a final “ready” version with a small list of remaining open questions (if any).

13. Create or update the Beads issue (must do)

   Create a new Beads issue, or update an existing issue, so that the description contains the full intake brief and links.

   - Type: `feature`
   - Priority: default to `2` unless the user indicates urgency/risk.
   - Title: `<descriptive working title>`

   The description must contain the final intake brief in Markdown format.

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   If there are `Related issues`, link them using `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type related`.

   If this issue is blocked by another then this should be recorded with `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type blocks`.

14. Finish

   After creating the issue, print:

   - The new Beads issue id
   - A 1–2 sentence summary
   - Close the response with "This completes the Intake process for <dead-id>"

parts.text:
You are running **Workflow step 1: intake brief** (see `docs/Workflow.md`, step 1).

Goal:

- Capture just enough context to decide whether the work needs:
  - a NEW PRD, or
  - an UPDATE to an existing PRD.
- Create a Beads issue to track the intake brief.
- Record all gathered information in the issue description.

Hard requirements:

- Use an **interview style**.
- Ask concise, high-signal questions.
- Soft-maximum of **three questions per iteration**.
- Do not invent requirements or constraints; if unknown, ask.
- Search the repo for related PRDs/specs and surface likely duplicates.
- Search Beads for related issues.
- Produce a short list of clarifying questions.
- Create a Beads issue to track the brief.

Argument handling:

- The user may optionally provide a short topic/title as `project initialization`.
  - If provided, treat it as a working title for the intake brief.
  - Do not attempt to parse flags/options.
- If `project initialization` is empty, ask the user for a short working title.

Process (must follow):


1. Interview (human-provided content)

   In multiple iterations (≤ 3 questions each), gather the following information (providing suggestions/examples informed by relevant context
   sources where helpful):

   - Problem (one paragraph)
     - What is the problem / opportunity?
     - Who experiences it (user personas)?
   - Success criteria (one paragraph)
     - What outcomes define success?
     - If possible, include a measurable target or a clear “done” test.
   - Constraints (one paragraph)
     - Compatibility expectations (what must not break)

   If the user indicates this is a change to something existing, also gather:

   - What exists today (current behavior)
   - What should change (desired behavior)
   - Where it likely lives (paths, commands, APIs)

2. Repo search (agent responsibility)

   Use the user’s answers to derive 2–6 keywords. Then search for related artifacts.

   - Search `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md` if present, Otherwise, scan `docs/`, `README.md`, and other high-level files for relevant context about the product/repo.
     - Use ripgrep where available (where not available use an alternative, but ask the user to install ripgrep).
     - Examples:
       - `rg -n "Product Requirements Document|\bPRD\b" docs/`
       - `rg -n "<keyword1>|<keyword2>" docs/ src/ README.md`
   - Search for related Beads issues covering this topic (duplicates / precursors):
     - Examples:
       - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
       - `bd ready --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, use a best-effort alternative and ask the user to install ripgrep.
     - If you find candidates:
       - List them as "Related issues" (ids + titles).
       - If one clearly already represents this work, prefer updating that issue (or creating a child issue) instead of creating a duplicate.
   - If you find candidates:
     - List them as "Likely duplicates / related docs".
     - Ask the user to confirm whether to update one of them.

3. Beads search (agent responsibility)

   Search existing issues for overlaps.

   - Use Beads as the source of truth.
   - Suggested approaches (pick the simplest available in the environment):
     - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, ask the user whether you should do a broad manual scan (and suggest the user installs ripgrep).

   Output:

   - "Related issues" list (ids + titles) OR explicitly state "No obvious related issues found".

4. Clarifying questions (agent responsibility)

   Produce a short list (0–7) of clarifying questions that would unblock PRD creation/editing.
   Keep them actionable and specific.

5. Decide next step: NEW PRD vs UPDATE

   Decide, then confirm with the user:

   - If UPDATE: identify the file path to update (ask for confirmation if uncertain).
   - If NEW: propose a PRD file path under `docs/dev/`.
     - Convention: `docs/dev/<feature>_PRD.md`.

6. Feedback Gate

  Propose the description of the bead, priority level, parent, related isses etc.

  Ask the user if there are any clarifictions, changes or further research required before proceeding. Carry out any further instructtions before proceeding. 

  Only proceed to the next step if the user gives permission to do so.

7. Draft the intake brief (agent responsibility)

   Compile all gathered information into a well-structured intake brief in Markdown format.

   Use the following template:

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

8. Review 1 (agent responsibility)

  Complete the **first full draft** of this workflow artifact for the current work item.
  - Be creative and propose strong defaults.
  - If uncertain, present 2-3 alternatives and choose one, explaining why.
  - Keep it actionable: concrete lists, commands, checklists, and examples.
  - Assume the reader wants momentum; do not over-polish yet.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

9. Review 2 (agent responsibilitY)

  Review the full draft for completeness, clarity, and actionability.
  - Ensure all required sections are present and well-structured.
  - Verify that all user-provided content is accurately captured.
  - Check for consistency in terminology and formatting.
  - Refine language for clarity and conciseness.
  - Ensure the proposed next steps are clear and actionable.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

10. Review 3 (Agent responsibility)

  Audit the current artifact for correctness and real-world usability.
  - Add missing constraints, assumptions, and decision points.
  - Add edge cases, failure modes, and "what could go wrong" notes.
  - Ensure steps are testable/verifiable.
  - Remove anything not serving the artifact purpose.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

11. Review 4 (Agent responsibility)

  Polish the artifact for clarity and fast reading.
  - Rewrite unclear sections and tighten wording.
  - Convert paragraphs into bullets/checklists where helpful.
  - Normalize terminology and naming.
  - Ensure examples/commands are copy-pastable and consistent.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

12. Final Review (Agent responsibility)

  Perform a final QA review of the artifact.
  - Check for internal consistency and contradictions.
  - Ensure it aligns with repo conventions and the Workflow doc.
  - Ensure every requirement is actionable and measurable.
  - Emit a final “ready” version with a small list of remaining open questions (if any).

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review, followed by the final artifact content.

13. Create or update the Beads issue (must do)

   Create a new Beads issue, or update an existing issue, so that the description contains the full intake brief and links.

   - Type: `feature`
   - Priority: default to `2` unless the user indicates urgency/risk.
   - Title: `<descriptive working title>`

   The description must contain the final intake brief in Markdown format.

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   If there are `Related issues`, link them using `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type related`.

   If this issue is blocked by another then this should be recorded with `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type blocks`.

14. Finish

   After creating the issue, print:

   - The new Beads issue id
   - A 1–2 sentence summary
   - Close the response with "This completes the Intake process for <dead-id>"

parts.text: 1) Project Initialization 2) WAIF uses a number of local configuration files for WAIF, Beads and Opencode (and maybe others). In order to use WAIF in a new project these configuration files need to be copied into the project directory. Provide a `waif init` command that will initialize a project with these key files. 3) this is new. Success criteria is that running `cd project_dir; waif init; ./scripts/start-workflow-tmux.sh` starts a tmux session in which the panes are correctly configured for a complete WAIF workflow.

parts.text:
review the process in `.opencode/command/intake.md` and update it to have roughly the same format as this PRD command, keeping the parts that are unique to issue intake and optimizing the parts that are common. If possible improve the PRD command based on what you learn from the intake command. The goal of the intake command is to I use this to say `/intake  As a [role] I need to [action] so that [result]` - the AI then conducts a project context review and a short interview with the user, writes a "key details" draft for the issue description, along with related work, asks me for any needed clarifications/alterations then reviews it 5 times, with the following "mini prompts" for each review. 

Each review outputs a brief summary of the edits and finally spits out the full description for approval before creating the final issue.

parts.text:
You are running **Workflow step 1: intake brief** (see `docs/Workflow.md`, step 1).

Goal:

- Capture just enough context to decide whether the work needs:
  - a NEW PRD, or
  - an UPDATE to an existing PRD.
- Create a Beads issue to track the intake brief.
- Record all gathered information in the issue description.

Hard requirements:

- Use an **interview style**.
- Ask concise, high-signal questions.
- Soft-maximum of **three questions per iteration**.
- Do not invent requirements or constraints; if unknown, ask.
- Search the repo for related PRDs/specs and surface likely duplicates.
- Search Beads for related issues.
- Produce a short list of clarifying questions.
- Create a Beads issue to track the brief.

Argument handling:

- The user may optionally provide a short topic/title as `As a PM I need to take a PRD and break it down into Beads that can each be implemented by our engineers so that I can optimize the use of our resources. The resulting beeds graph should ensure that dependencies are clearly recorded, blockers are identified and relationships are recorded. Each bead should result in observable and testable progress towards a specific goal. If a single bead is too large in scope it should be broken down into children that can be implemented independently. This whole process should be delivered as a .opencode/command/plan.md command.`.
  - If provided, treat it as a working title for the intake brief.
  - Do not attempt to parse flags/options.
- If `As a PM I need to take a PRD and break it down into Beads that can each be implemented by our engineers so that I can optimize the use of our resources. The resulting beeds graph should ensure that dependencies are clearly recorded, blockers are identified and relationships are recorded. Each bead should result in observable and testable progress towards a specific goal. If a single bead is too large in scope it should be broken down into children that can be implemented independently. This whole process should be delivered as a .opencode/command/plan.md command.` is empty, ask the user for a short working title.

Process (must follow):


1. Interview (human-provided content)

   In multiple iterations (≤ 3 questions each), gather the following information (providing suggestions/examples informed by relevant context
   sources where helpful):

   - Problem (one paragraph)
     - What is the problem / opportunity?
     - Who experiences it (user personas)?
   - Success criteria (one paragraph)
     - What outcomes define success?
     - If possible, include a measurable target or a clear “done” test.
   - Constraints (one paragraph)
     - Compatibility expectations (what must not break)

   If the user indicates this is a change to something existing, also gather:

   - What exists today (current behavior)
   - What should change (desired behavior)
   - Where it likely lives (paths, commands, APIs)

2. Repo search (agent responsibility)

   Use the user’s answers to derive 2–6 keywords. Then search for related artifacts.

   - Search `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md` if present, Otherwise, scan `docs/`, `README.md`, and other high-level files for relevant context about the product/repo.
     - Use ripgrep where available (where not available use an alternative, but ask the user to install ripgrep).
     - Examples:
       - `rg -n "Product Requirements Document|\bPRD\b" docs/`
       - `rg -n "<keyword1>|<keyword2>" docs/ src/ README.md`
   - Search for related Beads issues covering this topic (duplicates / precursors):
     - Examples:
       - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
       - `bd ready --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, use a best-effort alternative and ask the user to install ripgrep.
     - If you find candidates:
       - List them as "Related issues" (ids + titles).
       - If one clearly already represents this work, prefer updating that issue (or creating a child issue) instead of creating a duplicate.
   - If you find candidates:
     - List them as "Likely duplicates / related docs".
     - Ask the user to confirm whether to update one of them.

3. Beads search (agent responsibility)

   Search existing issues for overlaps.

   - Use Beads as the source of truth.
   - Suggested approaches (pick the simplest available in the environment):
     - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, ask the user whether you should do a broad manual scan (and suggest the user installs ripgrep).

   Output:

   - "Related issues" list (ids + titles) OR explicitly state "No obvious related issues found".

4. Clarifying questions (agent responsibility)

   Produce a short list (0–7) of clarifying questions that would unblock PRD creation/editing.
   Keep them actionable and specific.

5. Decide next step: NEW PRD vs UPDATE

   Decide, then confirm with the user:

   - If UPDATE: identify the file path to update (ask for confirmation if uncertain).
   - If NEW: propose a PRD file path under `docs/dev/`.
     - Convention: `docs/dev/<feature>_PRD.md`.

6. Feedback Gate

  Propose the description of the bead, priority level, parent, related isses etc.

  Ask the user if there are any clarifictions, changes or further research required before proceeding. Carry out any further instructtions before proceeding. 

  Only proceed to the next step if the user gives permission to do so.

7. Draft the intake brief (agent responsibility)

   Compile all gathered information into a well-structured intake brief in Markdown format.

   Use the following template:

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

8. Review 1 (agent responsibility)

  Complete the **first full draft** of this workflow artifact for the current work item.
  - Be creative and propose strong defaults.
  - If uncertain, present 2-3 alternatives and choose one, explaining why.
  - Keep it actionable: concrete lists, commands, checklists, and examples.
  - Assume the reader wants momentum; do not over-polish yet.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

9. Review 2 (agent responsibilitY)

  Review the full draft for completeness, clarity, and actionability.
  - Ensure all required sections are present and well-structured.
  - Verify that all user-provided content is accurately captured.
  - Check for consistency in terminology and formatting.
  - Refine language for clarity and conciseness.
  - Ensure the proposed next steps are clear and actionable.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

10. Review 3 (Agent responsibility)

  Audit the current artifact for correctness and real-world usability.
  - Add missing constraints, assumptions, and decision points.
  - Add edge cases, failure modes, and "what could go wrong" notes.
  - Ensure steps are testable/verifiable.
  - Remove anything not serving the artifact purpose.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

11. Review 4 (Agent responsibility)

  Polish the artifact for clarity and fast reading.
  - Rewrite unclear sections and tighten wording.
  - Convert paragraphs into bullets/checklists where helpful.
  - Normalize terminology and naming.
  - Ensure examples/commands are copy-pastable and consistent.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

12. Final Review (Agent responsibility)

  Perform a final QA review of the artifact.
  - Check for internal consistency and contradictions.
  - Ensure it aligns with repo conventions and the Workflow doc.
  - Ensure every requirement is actionable and measurable.
  - Emit a final “ready” version with a small list of remaining open questions (if any).

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review, followed by the final artifact content.

13. Create or update the Beads issue (must do)

   Create a new Beads issue, or update an existing issue, so that the description contains the full intake brief and links.

   - Type: `feature`
   - Priority: default to `2` unless the user indicates urgency/risk.
   - Title: `<descriptive working title>`

   The description must contain the final intake brief in Markdown format.

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   If there are `Related issues`, link them using `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type related`.

   If this issue is blocked by another then this should be recorded with `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type blocks`.

14. Finish

   After creating the issue, print:

   - The new Beads issue id
   - A 1–2 sentence summary
   - Close the response with "This completes the Intake process for <dead-id>"

     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   If there are `Related issues`, link them using `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type related`.

   If this issue is blocked by another then this should be recorded with `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type blocks`.

14. Finish

   After creating the issue, print:

   - The new Beads issue id
   - A 1–2 sentence summary
   - Close the response with "This completes the Intake process for <dead-id>"

properties.name: intake
properties.arguments: As a PM I need to take a PRD and break it down into Beads that can each be implemented by our engineers so that I can optimize the use of our resources. The resulting beeds graph should ensure that dependencies are clearly recorded, blockers are identified and relationships are recorded. Each bead should result in observable and testable progress towards a specific goal. If a single bead is too large in scope it should be broken down into children that can be implemented independently. This whole process should be delivered as a .opencode/command/plan.md command.

parts.text: The primary epic should not be top level, it should be a child af an approriate issue. The issue ID will be provided when the command is given and it should contain the necessary information such a links to the PRD. When the command is run the format is `/plan bd-123`, it defaults to auto-create and thus does not need the switch for that. Thre is no need for a fuzzy-match. Make the auto-create threshold 25 beads. The plan should not include estimates. remove the proposed next steps.

title:
You are scribbler (docs agent). Work to perform autonomously:

1) Edit docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md to add a new section titled "Per-bead worklog & state" that defines a concise, line-oriented worklog format and guidance for stor...[TRUNCATED]

parts.text:
You are scribbler (docs agent). Work to perform autonomously:

1) Edit docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md to add a new section titled "Per-bead worklog & state" that defines a concise, line-oriented worklog format and guidance for storing it in beads. Follow these acceptance criteria (copied from bd wf-rjh):
  - Define a concise line-oriented worklog format: ISO 8601 UTC timestamp, actor, short action, resulting state, optional link/reference. Example: "2025-12-31T20:00:00Z @alice claim -> in_progress #link-to-bd"
  - Define canonical place to store the worklog: a bead comment block prefixed with "WORKLOG:" (preferred for human-readable audit) and also define bead metadata fields "worklog" (array) and "workflow_state" (single value) for tool consumption. Explain when to use a comment vs metadata.
  - Provide 3 realistic example entries: claim/in_progress, handoff, close. Include a full sample bead comment block showing multiple entries.
  - Recommend length/char limits (e.g., 200 chars per entry), privacy guidance (avoid secrets), and retention guidance (keep entries concise; archive if large) 
  - Add a short 'Usage checklist for agents' with steps agents must follow when updating beads: add a worklog entry, set workflow_state metadata, add discovered-from/deps if needed, and add a bd comment referencing edited files.
  - Provide one-paragraph rationale for the change.

2) Update staging: commit the change on the current branch (wf-rjh/add-worklog-prd) with message "docs(prd): add per-bead worklog & workflow_state convention (wf-rjh)".

3) Create a GitHub PR using gh with title "docs(prd): add per-bead worklog & workflow_state convention (wf-rjh)" and a PR body that includes:
  - Summary bullet points of what's changed
  - The one-paragraph rationale
  - Link/reference to bd wf-rjh
  - Note that branch includes pre-existing edit .opencode/command/intake.md

4) Return the PR URL and list of files changed.

Constraints:
- Update only docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md (plus commits and PR). Do not change other files besides staging committed earlier (.opencode and .beads already committed).
- Ensure PR references bd wf-rjh in the body.
- If gh CLI is unavailable, prepare the PR body and stop; report what you would run.

Respond with only a JSON object containing keys: status (success|failed), pr_url (string|null), files_changed (array of paths), message (short human-readable).

parts.text:
You are running **Workflow step 1: intake brief** (see `docs/Workflow.md`, step 1).

Goal:

- Capture just enough context to decide whether the work needs:
  - a NEW PRD, or
  - an UPDATE to an existing PRD.
- Create a Beads issue to track the intake brief.
- Record all gathered information in the issue description.

Hard requirements:

- Use an **interview style**.
- Ask concise, high-signal questions.
- Soft-maximum of **three questions per iteration**.
- Do not invent requirements or constraints; if unknown, ask.
- Search the repo for related PRDs/specs and surface likely duplicates.
- Search Beads for related issues.
- Produce a short list of clarifying questions.
- Create a Beads issue to track the brief.

Argument handling:

- The user may optionally provide a short topic/title as `waif intake command`.
  - If provided, treat it as a working title for the intake brief.
  - Do not attempt to parse flags/options.
- If `waif intake command` is empty, ask the user for a short working title.

Process (must follow):


1. Interview (human-provided content)

   In multiple iterations (≤ 3 questions each), gather the following information (providing suggestions/examples informed by relevant context
   sources where helpful):

   - Problem (one paragraph)
     - What is the problem / opportunity?
     - Who experiences it (user personas)?
   - Success criteria (one paragraph)
     - What outcomes define success?
     - If possible, include a measurable target or a clear “done” test.
   - Constraints (one paragraph)
     - Compatibility expectations (what must not break)

   If the user indicates this is a change to something existing, also gather:

   - What exists today (current behavior)
   - What should change (desired behavior)
   - Where it likely lives (paths, commands, APIs)

2. Repo search (agent responsibility)

   Use the user’s answers to derive 2–6 keywords. Then search for related artifacts.

   - Search `docs/dev/CONTEXT_PACK.md` if present, Otherwise, scan `docs/`, `README.md`, and other high-level files for relevant context about the product/repo.
     - Use ripgrep where available (where not available use an alternative, but ask the user to install ripgrep).
     - Examples:
       - `rg -n "Product Requirements Document|\bPRD\b" docs/`
       - `rg -n "<keyword1>|<keyword2>" docs/ src/ README.md`
   - Search for related Beads issues covering this topic (duplicates / precursors):
     - Examples:
       - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
       - `bd ready --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, use a best-effort alternative and ask the user to install ripgrep.
     - If you find candidates:
       - List them as "Related issues" (ids + titles).
       - If one clearly already represents this work, prefer updating that issue (or creating a child issue) instead of creating a duplicate.
   - If you find candidates:
     - List them as "Likely duplicates / related docs".
     - Ask the user to confirm whether to update one of them.

3. Beads search (agent responsibility)

   Search existing issues for overlaps.

   - Use Beads as the source of truth.
   - Suggested approaches (pick the simplest available in the environment):
     - `bd list --status open --json | rg -i "<keyword>"`
     - If `rg` is unavailable, ask the user whether you should do a broad manual scan (and suggest the user installs ripgrep).

   Output:

   - "Related issues" list (ids + titles) OR explicitly state "No obvious related issues found".

4. Clarifying questions (agent responsibility)

   Produce a short list (0–7) of clarifying questions that would unblock PRD creation/editing.
   Keep them actionable and specific.

5. Decide next step: NEW PRD vs UPDATE

   Decide, then confirm with the user:

   - If UPDATE: identify the file path to update (ask for confirmation if uncertain).
   - If NEW: propose a PRD file path under `docs/dev/`.
     - Convention: `docs/dev/<feature>_PRD.md`.

6. Feedback Gate

  Propose the description of the bead, priority level, parent, related isses etc.

  Ask the user if there are any clarifictions, changes or further research required before proceeding. Carry out any further instructtions before proceeding. 

  Only proceed to the next step if the user gives permission to do so.

7. Draft the intake brief (agent responsibility)

   Compile all gathered information into a well-structured intake brief in Markdown format.

   Use the following template:

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

8. Review 1 (agent responsibility)

  Complete the **first full draft** of this workflow artifact for the current work item.
  - Be creative and propose strong defaults.
  - If uncertain, present 2-3 alternatives and choose one, explaining why.
  - Keep it actionable: concrete lists, commands, checklists, and examples.
  - Assume the reader wants momentum; do not over-polish yet.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

9. Review 2 (agent responsibilitY)

  Review the full draft for completeness, clarity, and actionability.
  - Ensure all required sections are present and well-structured.
  - Verify that all user-provided content is accurately captured.
  - Check for consistency in terminology and formatting.
  - Refine language for clarity and conciseness.
  - Ensure the proposed next steps are clear and actionable.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

10. Review 3 (Agent responsibility)

  Audit the current artifact for correctness and real-world usability.
  - Add missing constraints, assumptions, and decision points.
  - Add edge cases, failure modes, and "what could go wrong" notes.
  - Ensure steps are testable/verifiable.
  - Remove anything not serving the artifact purpose.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

11. Review 4 (Agent responsibility)

  Polish the artifact for clarity and fast reading.
  - Rewrite unclear sections and tighten wording.
  - Convert paragraphs into bullets/checklists where helpful.
  - Normalize terminology and naming.
  - Ensure examples/commands are copy-pastable and consistent.

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review.

12. Final Review (Agent responsibility)

  Perform a final QA review of the artifact.
  - Check for internal consistency and contradictions.
  - Ensure it aligns with repo conventions and the Workflow doc.
  - Ensure every requirement is actionable and measurable.
  - Emit a final “ready” version with a small list of remaining open questions (if any).

  Output a summary of any changes made during this review, followed by the final artifact content.

13. Create or update the Beads issue (must do)

   Create a new Beads issue, or update an existing issue, so that the description contains the full intake brief and links.

   - Type: `feature`
   - Priority: default to `2` unless the user indicates urgency/risk.
   - Title: `<descriptive working title>`

   The description must contain the final intake brief in Markdown format.

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   - Problem
   - Users
   - Success criteria
   - Constraints
   - Existing state (if applicable)
   - Desired change (if applicable)
   - Likely duplicates / related docs (file paths)
   - Related issues (Beads ids)
   - Clarifying questions
   - Proposed next step:
     - `NEW PRD` at: `<path>` OR
     - `UPDATE PRD` at: `<path>`
     - Recommended next command: `/prd <path> <new-issue-id>`

   If there is a suitable parent issue then create the new issue as a sub-issue (use `--parent <id>`).

   If there are `Related issues`, link them using `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type related`.

   If this issue is blocked by another then this should be recorded with `bd dep add [issue-id] [depends-on-id] --type blocks`.

14. Finish

   After creating the issue, print:

   - The new Beads issue id
   - A 1–2 sentence summary
   - Close the response with "This completes the Intake process for <dead-id>"

title: You are scribbler (docs agent). Task: update docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md so it aligns with the updated docs/Workflow.md which now defines named steps: Project Definition, Define Milestones, Feature Decomposition, Vertical Slices...[TRUNCATED]

parts.text:
You are scribbler (docs agent). Task: update docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md so it aligns with the updated docs/Workflow.md which now defines named steps: Project Definition, Define Milestones, Feature Decomposition, Vertical Slices. Make a minimal set of edits: replace ad-hoc stage example wording with a canonical token list and a short mapping to the Workflow.md named steps. Requirements:

1) Read these files (they are in the repo): docs/Workflow.md and docs/dev/workflow_stage_tracking_PRD.md. Use the exact human-facing step names from docs/Workflow.md in your mapping text.

2) Replace the sentence in the PRD introduction that currently lists example stages (line around "It can be hard for humans to track what stage a feature is at (idea, PRD, plan, implementation, etc.)") so it references the Workflow.md named steps and mentions the canonical bead-stage tokens.
